content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												Polarity is a first person logic puzzle game whose concept is vastly inspired by Portal. It has similar mechanics but at the same time it is full of originality. The companion cubes might not be as cute as in Portal, but they’re still present in this game and needed to complete the puzzles. An innovation consists in the ability of the player to switch between two polarities (red – blue) which allows him to run through gates or to jump on platforms, according to the selected polarity.The single player part consists of 14 puzzles that are not too hard to solve, with difficulty increasing  each level though. However, even the most difficult levels can be solved in less than 5 minutes each. The 10 bonus levels are slightly more difficult to figure out, but they add new fun features to the game.The coop mode, on the other hand, is quite challenging. The two players must cooperate to solve the puzzles that are much more complex than in single player mode. The levels are bigger, now consisting in multiple rooms. The path to the exit isn’t usually the same for the two players, but nevertheless, they need to work together to reach it. There are places in which timed jumps are needed while trying to grab certain objects at the same time, and these jumps are not easily performed with a controller as compared to a mouse and keyboard setup. Sadly, the game offers only local coop and not online multiplayer, so make sure to invite a friend that can be persuaded to work on those together with you, without him losing his patience. Or even better, maybe you can convince him/her to do those tricky jumps :)Don’t hesitate to buy it, especially discounted, since it is a very fun game!More reviews on the Lilly's Corner Curator page

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												QUICK NOTE: At the time I'm writing this, the game is on sale at $0.54 (95% off). At that price, I could recommend the game, sure. Unless you absolutely cannot get enough first person puzzle/platforming, I wouldn't get it otherwise, especially not at $10.99.---You play as a hacker that is being paid (presumably) a large amount of money to hack into a level and steal data through some physical manifestation of your target's... network? Mainframe? God knows. The point is you have to go through 12 levels (followed by another 10 bonus levels), collecting 3 Data Fragments per level.The main gimmick of the game is that you can switch your "Polarity" at will - between red and blue. While a certain color, you will collide with objects of the opposite color (such as lasers, which will kill you), but pass through objects of the same color. There are also cubes (pretty much tiny Companion Cubes) which behave in a similar fashion. The cubes will power things when plugged into a slot, very similar to how Companion Cubes could hold buttons down to keep platforms suspended, etc. in Portal. Add a couple generic objects, such as launch pads and moving platforms, and you pretty much have the entire game.The game unabashedly takes a lot of inspiration from Portal: levels feel like sterile, self-contained test chambers, the only difference is that everything's dark grey instead of white, and you don't have a charming robot voice monologuing you or telling a story while you progress; the large and open, but still linear level design; and a general futuristic theme (though it's admittedly silly to mash both Portal and Polarity into such a vast genre and expect it to mean anything). You don't need to collect the 3 Data Fragments to technically "beat" the level - rather, you can simply progress through the level and find the exit. This is where most of the difficulty comes from. However, Data Fragments are required to unlock the next levels. They are usually poorly hidden, if not put directly in plain sight, and by simply walking around the room you can easily tell how to get to the fragments. The worst the game will do is put them behind a small puzzle, or out of your immediate field of view when you enter a room. To put it into perspective, the only levels I needed to play more than once were the first and second levels, where I missed one fragment each, because it was placed slightly out of sight or in a corner that I had carelessly overlooked.It doesn't feel good to collect data fragments because the level design is not challenging at all. The main "puzzle" in each level often requires next to no thinking. I beat all 22 single-player levels in about 50 minutes, and was fairly bored the entire way through. Sadly, this is why I can't say I recommend this title.It's not that the art style is uninspired and simple - that doesn't necessarily make a game bad.It's not that the music, and the general sound design for that matter, has a generic, forgettable 80s futuristic feel, which I'd normally think was quite humorous or charming - lots of devs these days just use stock royalty-free music and nobody seems to mind that too much. At least this has custom music (I think).It's not that it's trying to copy Portal - I don't see a huge amount wrong with following the footsteps of a very successful puzzle game and trying to recreate that formula!It's not even that the first person animations, head bobbing, and movement glitches make it painfully obvious this is a 3D Unity game. Or that my Logitech F310 - a fairly good controller when it comes to compatibility - would only work during the main menu and the two "cutscenes" that exist in singleplayer.The problem is the frankly depressing lack of content, and, more importantly, the content that IS there is unchallenging, unengaging, and simply not fun. As a developer, I'd be disappointed if I spent a significant amount of time and effort building a game and only could be bothered to make a few mediocre-at-best levels that don't even show the potential of what few mechanics that DO exist. As a consumer, I'm very confused with how this game has so many positive reviews - must just be me being out of touch with the puzzle game community. Don't expect level design that lives up to Portal, or any other good puzzle game I can think of, really.TL;DR - Game's really dry on content, and what content DID manage to find its way in is insultingly easy and boring. I'd say it's worth neither your time nor your money. Get on a crazy 95% off sale, if at all.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
Polarity is a fun little puzzle game, whether you are in for some achievement hunting or simply want to face some brain challenges. However, note that this game's stages are nowhere near the level of other puzzles games such as Portal or The Talos Principle. Most of the levels in Polarity won't leave you thinking for more than 2 or 3 minutes, sometimes the solution is painfully obvious, making the completion of this game feel rushed, even though there are 20 levels attached to it.The goal of the game is to reach the end chamber of each level (similar to the Portal series). In doing so, you have to make use of red and blue cubes in order to activate different mechanisms. In addition, you can change your player's "polarity" from red to blue and vice-versa. This is mainly useful because some walls only allow you to pass through them if you are in their specific polarity.We are presented with a poor attempt at a story, which will not matter in the slightest throughout the game and only serves as a filler. However, this isn't anything important if you don't care much about a storyline. Polarity is, after all, a puzzle game.The game looks pretty, visuals are nothing too impressive, but they're on point for its genre. Unfortunately, the game seems unpolished. There are glitches, some slightly unfinished areas, while the places which represent abyssal falls are literally... void, leaving the map in a lackluster state.The music is pretty much alright. Fortunately, there's a couple of songs attached to it, so the same tune will not repeat through each level.The store page of the game claims to feature a multiplayer factor. However, this is partly true. You can only play a local co-op campaign with your friend, on the same computer, using either a keyboard and a controller, or two controllers.Summary:Pros: + Fun little game to kill time with and relax;+ Overall a nice simplistic approach to games such as Portal;+ Collectibles and achievements, as well as the co-op campaign, encourage replayability;+ Ambient music that fits the game's setting;Cons: - Some people will find the experience lacking, due to the easy challenges and small amount of gameplay mechanics; in addition, this may lead to a fast completion of the game, maybe too fast for its price;- Unfinished, visually speaking; the pits that serve as obstacles are pitch black, as if parts of the map are just missing;- Even though a multiplayer feature is out of the question, since the player base is pretty much dead, a more advanced co-op feature would be appreciated, letting players play with their friends, each on their own system;- Occasional bugs here and there;Personal rating: 62/100 - Decent

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												There’s a sad irony to how Polarity succeeds at being both bloated with ideas and creatively bankrupt.Every few levels it throws out a new mechanic - binary colored platforms, rotating switches, color changing portals, to name a few - but it barely gives time to show how they function before it decides to move onto something new. The constant stream of introductions to tools that are barely utilized keeps Polarity from ever managing to create puzzles that provide any sort of challenge.From the main campaign, to the coop levels, and even the bonus stages (which could have just as well been included with the other levels as they feel identical) every puzzle is agonizingly mundane and basic. Polarity mingles in tutorials from start to finish, as if testing my patience for repeating the same handful of puzzle types for hours on end, chuckling to itself at how cleverly it has hidden its simplicity by placing it within tediously large levels that have a habit of breaking halfway through and forcing you to restart.The cooperative mode itself feels like almost a misnomer, allowing two players to go through levels together but rarely if ever requiring they work together, or even giving both players something to do. Often one of us would simply took over completing a puzzle while the other trailed behind waiting for their turn to help, with a few instances of actual cooperation being the sole highlight of the game.There just doesn’t seem to be any point to Polarity. It exists for the sake of existing but in a post-Portal world and an increasingly crowded genre, it feels trite and uninspired. I could potentially see a lot of things from it being spun out into better games, but it’s hard to imagine that ever happening when what’s already here is so disinterested in moving forward.You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

"ONE OF THE MOST FUN PUZZLE/PLATFORMERS SINCE PORTAL"Alright, look at the statement above and then look at the Polarity. You see some confusion and/or incorrect statement right? Well, yes, and that one is coming straight from the guys behind game. What a promo. This has nothing to do with Portal, it ain't have portals and it certainly ain't have guns. Only thing that these two games have in common is first two latters in their name "PO"Polarity is usual type of indie game - puzzle & platformer. And also Polarity is usual type of game that is hiding behind term "indie" Man, that guy who come up with that idea of abusing indie to cover BS, should get medal. For real. Now I'm not saying game is utterly boring, it's fun at the beginning and out of those 3 hours at least 1 will be good. Just after that you get bored.If you want to get everything, game will last you around 3 hours. "Story" yes "story" itself is under hour, then there is local CO-OP that will add another one. People asked for online CO-OP but I don't really think that would make any big difference. Game have as always trading cards and also 10 easy achievements.Price point is 9,99 which is definitely not price you'd want to get it for. At the time of writing this (10/4/2017) it's in 90% off for 0,99 so this is time to get it. Soundtrack was relatively pretty nice, and it's also in discount for 0,49 so you can get that one also.Now I really have to quit with these bellow or just average "indie" games because when I get my hands on some AAA most definitely I'll be dead from ♥♥♥♥♥♥.Bonus Point: Portal thingie was a lie!Rating: 5/10

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
"Blue or red forcefields?"Polarity looks on the first view like a cheap "Portal" rip off. But after playing it through it's mostly relaxing puzzle fun. Instead of using portals you carry and throw little cubes to switches. There are also switchable bouncers and moving platforms. But most important are the red and blue energy fields and your color change ability. We know this from "The Flip". Well, the puzzles get more complex and challenging on higher stages.For example you must fall through 5 alternating colored laserfields. If you have the wrong color you die. In each level there are 3 hidden data pieces to collect. The Coop levels are no real internet coop (they are just local coop). But with an additional gamepad controller + keyboard they are quite doable on your own. Altogether very joyful.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Sometimes, it isn't one big thing, but a lot of little things.  In this case, that lot of little things make me feel like I'm playing a university student's final project for their game design class rather than a Real Game That You Pay Money For And Stuff.Here are some examples, in no particular order: There appear to be at most twelve to fifteen different textures for the entire game.  Many puzzle elements appear to be deliberately constructed to minimize the number and complexity of their textures.  To the game's credit, what textures do exist are visually distinctive, rather than the twenty or thirty variations on "industrial, brown, and ugly" you will find in more than a few "modern" games. The game's plot appears on a series of simple dialog boxes, and appears to have nothing whatsoever to do with the gameplay except insofar as it dictates the names of a few puzzle elements here and there. The game presents dual controller/keyboard+mouse prompts everywhere, except for a few places where it displays controller prompts only.  It does not adjust the prompts based on the input method, nor is it capable of accepting keyboard+mouse input while in controller mode (or vice-versa).  It does (apparently) try to guess the correct input mode, but I only know this because it guessed wrong. The "data fragments" you are expected to collect are in many cases simply scattered about the level.  Finding them is an easter-egg hunt, not a puzzle challenge as with (e.g.) the stars in the Talos Principle.  This appears to largely stem from the baffling design choice to provide a fixed three fragments per (short) level rather than making them rare and irregular enough to be interesting. The cubes you can pick up do not respect the inertia of a moving platform.  If you drop them onto a (horizontally) moving platform, the cubes will stay where they are and fall off. The game has somewhat limited animation.  Buttons do not depress when activated.  Objects are destroyed by instantly replacing them with untextured particle effects. The menus are mostly static and not very pretty.  They do not take advantage of the high resolution of my monitor.  This is not to say they are pixelated or otherwise mangled; they just aren't all that pleasant to look at.The smoking gun, of course, is the "readme" on the game's main menu, which informs us that the game was made by a small group of people coding it "in their bedrooms," whatever that's supposed to mean.  Ordinarily this would inspire lenience in me, especially since I paid a mere $1.50 for it.  But the note then goes on to exhort the player to purchase the game if they enjoyed it, which suggests to me it was intended for a demo and (accidentally?) included in the final copy.  Combine that with a complete lack of such a warning on the main store page, and I'm just not inclined to give them the benefit of the doubt here.Nevertheless, it is better than nothing.  Buy it when it's 90% off.

Posted: August 23, 2015
												I gotta say that Polarity is a short, but fun experience in my books, but anyway here's the review:So far, Polarity is a really fun, short, but simple game to play. It consists of 37 levels, including co-op levels, which some of them can be challenging, but not to the point of frustration. You can also collect Data Fragments in each level, which are used to unlock more levels and add a little bit more fun to the game. The gameplay is very similar to Portal, but in a different way, and that's what makes this game unique. I find the graphics pretty good and I also love the music in this game! The ambience in the music fits perfectly inside of an obstacle course/ facility setting. This game also includes achievements and trading cards, which is also a plus.In conclusion, Polarity is just a casual and pretty fun game for people to play if they're bored and have nothing to do.Should you buy this game?If you're looking for a fun game to chill with, then Polarity is the game for you.9.5/10

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												Don't buy this game.This games feels unfinished an unpolished. It literally feels like I'm playing a university student's project,a demo,a free-to-play Unity game,rather than a fully fledged game.The game has loads of bugs. Clipping out of boundaries is stupidly easy.The art style is cheap and lazy, featuring stupidly bland colors.There is no plot,except for the "Cutscene" that explains that you are a hacker,and explains your goals. By the way, The 'Hacker' thing is a lie. You do absolutely nothing that makes you feel like a hacker. It feels like it's just a cheap excuse to explain the bland color of the levels,the uninspiringly empty and minimalistic design,and the plain use of solid colors.Textures are horrible and look pixelated when you look closely at them.Controls aren't bad,except by the fact that the mouse has this weird acceleration that you can't turn off or adjust.Cubes simply disappear and reappear when the 'Reset Cube' button is pressed,with no animation.Moving platforms behave weirdly. They just start and stop moving,again,with no animation, this without mentioning that the physics of cubes also behave in a very erratic way when on top of a moving platform.The UI,once again,features no animation.Entering or exiting a level also doesn't feature animation. You just hop from the level to the menu,from the menu to the level,because the developer did not even have the audacity to implement a simple fade-in and fade-outSound effects are horrible. The sound track isn't bad,though.The "puzzles"  go from super simple to super confusing,in a matter of minutes of gameplay. Some of them require you to kill yourself in order to progress. Does that look like good level design for you? It sure doesn't look good for me.All in all,don't buy this game.It is not worth it's price,not even on sale. It is a shameless waste of time and potential.If this was a free to play game,or a public alpha,it would be OK,but as a full game,its unacceptable,as it is nothing more than a poorly built 3D game built in Unity,that feels more like a student project,and that being said,there are better student projects out there.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
TL;DRDevs have strange practices and their game is buggy as all hellThis game may seem fun, but it's mediocre at bestLet me first give you a warning of the shady marketing/advertising this company practices. This game is around 2 years old, but the release date has changed multiple times. The developers claim this is a steam bug, but it has happened too often for it to not be suspicious and the developers try to dismiss the claim too much without providing any reasonable evidence.If those business practices haven't put you off the game, then maybe the actual game will.First off, I will talk about the general gameplay and what you do in this game. This game is a first person puzzle game. There are 12 regular levels; 10 bonus levels and 15 co-op levels (NOTE: The co-op levels are local co-op and use 1 keyboard and 1 controller, so don't think about playing with friends online). This game has FORCED mouse acceleration. There is no way I, or my other friends who have put more hours into this game than I have, have found a way to turn it off. The developers are also lazy, and do not bother to connect planes of the levels, as seen here[i.imgur.com] in level 9 where the walls and floor are not connected.The aim of the game is to solve puzzles in order to get to the end of the level. Most of this is done through picking up cubes and throwing them in receptors in order to activate certain things. There is also the 'polarity' aspect of this game in which you can change your 'polarity' from blue to red. For example, with blue polarity you can walk on red platforms and safely go through blue lasers. The opposite is true for red polarity. Some puzzles in this game are pretty fun to figure out, but most of them are incredibly easy.Now, the meat of the review: bugs.This game is rife with bugs. To demonstrate most of the found ones, Siglamii and I have created some videos showing them. For some bugs, there is more info in the video description about the bugs:List of bugs in video formReset boostMoving during end screenLeftover developer toolsClipping with developer toolsFrame advance while pausing Buggy cube collision Cube boost Ledge boost Wall boostCube clipping through wallsHigh cube jumpingThere are also strange framerate bugs that exist. On any frame rates other than 60, jumping might not register, and framerate also dictates momentum and jump height to some extent. For example, higher framerates make you jump lower and make your momentum more sensitive. Setting the graphics to simple will limit the framerate to 60; setting the graphics to medium will limit the framerate to 30 (if in windowed mode) and setting the graphics to gorgeous will cap the framerate to your monitors refresh rate. There is no reason for this.I hope reading this review has persuaded you not to support the developers with their questionable practices by purchasing their shambles of a game.Thanks to Buttravage, MHFSilver, Dungeonfire, Avetixz and Siglamii for helping the speedrun community and I find these bugs and thanks to Siglamii for helping me with the review and demonstrating the bugs.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												Polarity is a first person puzzler which is pretty easy and relaxing.It has taken some things from Portal but it also has alot of original mechanics.The game is kinda lacking story but thats fine.The gameplayIn Polarity you can switch you’re polarity to red or blue so you can pass through walls by being the same color or being the opposite color to walk to paths.You collect green things to unlock other levels.You can pick up cubes and put em in a button of a sort or throw them to it.There are jump pads they can also be on walls, there are also ones which you can turn around.There are polarity changers for cubes which is self-explanatory.And there are laser which kill you or destroy cubes.At last you have room switches which turn around rooms.There are 12 main missions and 12 bonus missions, and there’s coop also.It will probably take you around 2 hours to complete bonus and main missions.The game controls good on keyboard.StoryTheres not much of story youre hacking( aka collecting the green things ), and then at the end he gives you money and then he offers you a better job.AudioThe music is relaxing.Other effects sound like pretty basic sounds.GraphicsThis is a unity game so the setting are just presets and resolutions.The game doesnt look amazing but it does the job theres not really a artstyle.The only resolutions you have are 1280x720 1360x768 1366x768 and 1600x900.Other things there are three graphics presets : simple medium and gorgeous.then you have windowed mode and rebindable keys.Final verdictSimple fun first person puzzler with some elements of Portal and some original stuff,with good controls and mediocre graphics but lacking story of any kind.

number of helpful: 15 of 19 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14
Product received for free
												First of all, I would like to thank the staff of eq-games to provide me of this key. I hope that the key wasn't meant for writing a review ASAP since I found the code in my mailbox not that long ago and the mail dated back from may. I think I'd rather won this key in a giveaway of some sort on twitch. In any way I'm not going to let that influence my opinion.Polarity is a first person puzzle game where you are a node inside another persons's network/database/server (it is not clear) and you have to finish the puzzles to collect the data from your victim and to complete the hack. If you are bored with the story itself you can also try out coop mode, which you complete puzzles with two persons even including splitscreen which you can connect controllers so you both can play on the same pc. This sounds like an amazing feature, I enjoyed every splitscreen that you could play and it was an utter shame to remove that on any upcoming game. Also if the main story is finished there are about as many bonus levels to dig into. I did find the concept interesting and they certainly set the bar very high. When I opened the store page this immediately catched my eye: "One of the most fun puzzle/platformers since Portal. Polarity takes it to the next level, demanding all of your wits and reflexes."That is my main problem with the game, not the fact that it is comparing itself to Portal, but the fact that the execution of this concept is very poor. Okay I agree they have a lot of features to make the puzzles good like colored cubes, lasers, gates, jumping pads that you can rotate, bridges which you need to be the other color to be on top of them, and buttons that rotate a part of the room in front of you, gates that change the color of the object you throw in it or yourself (I don't think you could get in one of em so I couldn't test that). Those features literally made me decide to complete the game because they were pretty well done aside from the chance you may get stuck in an object. As a node you can swap in two colors, red and blue which were meant to make the puzzles more challenging but why limit yourself with only two colors? I think it could be more of a thinking game once you get multiple colors. Not to mention how buggy it sometimes is. The control setting is something you have to take a close look at but even then some glitches happen. For example I have set my forward key to E (standard color swap keys are Q and left ctrl) and whenever I wanted to move in the beginning it swapped my color while moving which made it impossible to complete the puzzles. To solve this I set this key different and that seemed to do the trick. The next problem to me is the fact that they did nothing with the story. They start of with a small intro telling you that you are a node hacking a computer. They could do something with that like make the map the inside of the motherboard or maybe give it a wallpaper with black background and green binary or something like that. Talking about the map that wasn't my favourite feature either. The map could, like I said before, be done better not only in idea but I think they are not familiar to corners. Whenever looking at the ground in the direction of a wall you may see an empty line where a corner should be (for ex Level 9) and sometimes there are corners but they are way too big making it harder to jump over them. Or you can see the floor sometimes not fully connected or stuff like that. The map is also a bit too big in some levels where it could be way smaller but every level had the same width and height of the map. The music was very silent but I didn't mind that because I picked my own music from youtube to play in the background. As for the data you have to collect, for most of the time it is not a challenge at all. Most of the time you just walk around the map a bit and find it convienently being behind a pillar or in the corner or so. I wish they did all the data placement like the few that needed a bit of thinking to get to. I was the least satisfied with the ending, even angry, they could've added a boss battle connecting it with the "story". For example that you as a node get detected by the computer you are infected and you need to escape the level before they erase you but they did nothing instead.  Actually they require you to collect all the data to unlock the next 'level' which turns out to be a simple text message saying "We're hiring you as a hacker now because your node succeeded, also you gain a million credits hooray" This game definitly has a good concept but the poor execution didn't do well in my book. I consider you only pick this up if you want to play a game just for the puzzles and don't mind the rest of the game.

												Product was NOT received for Free - but nearly since it was only pennies in a Bundle xDWhy do I like this game - simple - it's challenging and keeps you working, but is still relaxing & isn't crazy difficult.  The Solo campaign went really fast like passing some of the easier levels in 40 seconds.  The Co-op was a different story - definitely required teamwork - & timing your jumps & changing color quickly was more work.  I'm the guy who mutes the music in so many games - guess what - the background music/sound in Polarity was actually good.  I don't really see the Portal comparison that others have mentioned - this game stands just fine on its own.So, once you've been through it all, I guess you could try to beat your times or something - I didn't see much replayability.  On the up side, 100% Achievements should be no problem for you.  Fun & very much worth the Bundle price.  But, if I'd paid the retail $9.99, I'd be hopping mad LOL - Just saying!  The Developer(s) did a great job - Kudos!P.S. My actual play time is around 3-4hours (forgot it was running one night & that ran the time up, in case anybody wondered). Cheers!

number of helpful: 15 of 19 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												Hmm...If this were a concept demo or something, I guess I'd recommend trying it, but as a full game I'm disappointed. If I were more cynical, I would call this a moneymaking scheme, leveraging the Steam Trading Card system to get people to pick it up for 19-25 cents during sales and re-sell the cards for a small profit. However, I don't hold the developers responsible for this and I want to give this an honest review. If I were judging this as a concept demo, or in a game jam, or even on Steam Greenlight, I'd rate it very highly. I'm glad that Steam exists not just for big-budget studios to market games but also as a platform for small indie developers to try out unique concepts and hone their skills. I just feel like this game would work better on something like itch.io or gamejolt, in a pay-what-you-want market. As a finished game, I can't really recommend it.The core mechanic of Polarity - color swapping - isn't really new. Basically, walls/platforms block things the opposite color as them, lasers destroy things the opposite color as them, and boxes/buttons have to match colors to work. You can swap colors, you can change a box's color by sending it through a color-changing field. Oh, and don't touch green lasers. That's it. Not every game needs to be super innovative to be good; puzzle games can take simple/already existing ideas and turn them into good puzzles. The problem is, this game doesn't get that far. There's only a handful of very short levels, and they're all super easy, even the 'bonus levels'. In an hour, I completed 75% of the game (I started skipping to later levels once I started finding them easy). You don't really need to explore, or reason/plan solutions to puzzles, or do anything beyond the basic interactions. I'm not sure if this is because of the level design/lack of levels, or if the concept itself doesn't lend itself to difficult/interesting levels.It's also not polished. Level design is sometimes annoying: lots of wide open rooms without many puzzle elements (and a slow-ish walking speed), and there's really no point to the green lasers apart from making you return to a checkpoint. There's a general awkwardness to the movement (jump boosts and moving platforms are inconsistent, and held boxes get stuck on things really easily). Control setup is weird (it's Unity, so you can remap things, but there's a bunch of controls that aren't used/show up twice). The tutorial is really unnecessary (the game pauses to display button prompts when a simple tooltip saying "WASD, Spacebar, Q, click, have fun" would have been more than enough).Polarity doesn't really have much else going for it (I guess controller support and local multiplayer are kind of neat considering the suprising number of big-budget games without these features, but again they're auxiliary to the main experience and they don't really affect my overall review).So ultimately, who would I recommend this to? My friends that already enjoy puzzles would finish it within minutes, and my friends that are new to the genre would probably enjoy something that's more polished/complete. Despite all that, this game does a few interesting things right: Gameplay elements within the levels have a very clear and consistent visual design. There's subtle hints that players might use without noticing (like a white square/black frame that means 'throw a box at this from far away') and platform placement/wall design actually guides players toward the optional objectives. The system of checkpoints is actually really well done (most games like this make you restart levels completely). Despite my earlier complaints, the level design is pretty good overall, and it's clear that effort and time was put into this experience. Sadly, as a finished game I can't recommend it.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
TL;DRIf it's on sale, pick it up for a quick whirl. Alternatively, if you have a child and Portal is too difficult for him/her (or if he/she has a strong phobia of cake), then consider this game instead. Otherwise, save the money.Another Portal Clone without the HeartFrom a technical standpoint, this game really isn't bad. The levels are actually pretty well designed, especially some of the co-op missions. But if you look past the chocolately outer layer, you'll find that the game lacks the nougaty center that Portal provides. There's no real story, the whole "hacker" bit only manisfests itself in the naming of certain things, but has no bearing on the gameplay. And overall, the gameplay is quite lackluster.And honestly, I'd might be okay with having no story if it wasn't for the fact that the game is just sooooo easy. There's no challenge. Once you get the hang of timing polarity switches in mid-air, which any competent gamer will have down by the fifth level, the game doesn't get any more challenging than that. The whole "data-collection" bit is also a bit contrived. Originally, they seems like optional collectibles that add some kind of difficulty, until you realize that they're necessary to progress the game.BreakdownPros Not too gimmicky, sticks with core mechanics pretty wellCons Just boring. It's uneventful, there's no story, the gameplay doesn't challenge the user. It's like flavorless pudding, there's nothing wrong with it, but why would I get it when there's all these other better tasing ones around. Had issues a few times where my character would clip out of bounds for no reason. I'd just fall out of the map and fall endlessly down until I restarted the level.Score: 5/10; Not good, not bad, right in the middle

Posted: July 13, 2016
												I didn't expect much when I picked that game up.I actually saw this game lying on the Steam Store shelf for a crazy 0,36 euros, so I had to check it out.Imagine Portal without portals and humor.It's the most basic 3D puzzle game you can imagine. It's not as boring as it sounds.It's super-short, for one thing. It's not a game you pick-up and replay over and over again.It's one of those "I've got nothing to play" kinda game.Everything seems alright, but after diging in I've found some flaws.Controller support is clunky and it doesn't always work. The menus are glitchy unless you disable the gamepad in the settings. For most people this game would probably bore you to death, but not me.I've sat through this thing and I actually found some impressive puzzles.For a game all about picking up things and throwing them, that's quire an accomplishment.I launched Vs mode just out of morbid curiosity. My brother just died in front of the monitor.It's not a fun multiplayer game to play. The rules are easy and there's no challenge.Combine that with gamepad controls and you've got yourself a nice nightmare session.The best thing about this game is the soundtrack. Spectrosconomy is probably the best track on the whole game. It's in the trailer and it deserves some recognition on SoundCloud.Go look it up and show Ludiotic some love.For the full price, avoid immediately.Wait for a crazy sale to make this game pay-off.It's not a novelty, but I think I could let this game pass.

												While the game is short and very cheap, I can personally say it's worth the five bucks! At first it was another game in my library, but once I actually installed it and tried it out, it was extremely awesome! content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												Polarity is a good puzzler, but don't be confused, it's not Portal. The puzzles were interesting, though I rarely thought it was really difficult in a way that stumped me. The hardest part is finding all the collectable "data" in the levels, and I'll admit I had quite a bit of fun looking for and getting to them all. The addition of a multiplayer mode was a HUGE plus, and was frankly a lot more fun than the standard game, in my opinion.The viusuals get the job done, but they aren't anything to write home about. (Also, it didn't natively support my 1440 x 900 resolution, so that was kinda a bummer.)  Also, there are a good number of bugs that still need to be worked out, and frankly rip you out of the experience. holes in the ground that drop you down to infinity and don't respawn you unless you restart the level aren't fun, and I've accidentally fallen down more than one. In summary, I'd say to pick this game up when it's on sale. I wouldn't spend the whole 5 bucks on it, but if it gets around a dollar it's definitely worth your time.

												Great game to play in co-op mode if you're a casual gamer. Sure, there is no intriguing story. Sure, some of the puzzles may be a little easy for the hardcore gamers. If you are into the background and story of games or into extremely difficult puzzles, this may not be the game for you.However, if you're planning on relaxing with a friend, jump on co-op campaign and you guys will have a great and laid-back experience. The soundtrack of this game is solid and very relaxing, the puzzles are in my experience very rewarding and the game feels polished.The only negative is that there is no online co-op: only split screen co-op and single player.I do not recommend paying the full €10.99 for this game though, as it often goes on sale for 95% (€0.54) and even 98% (€0.21). You can even make your money back by selling the trading cards! I would recommend everyone to get the game on sale and enjoy a few hours of relaxing gameplay. DO IT!!! JUST DO IT!!! Overall: 8.1/10

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
GameplayPolarity is a puzzle platformer that'll take you through 22 levels (12 campaign levels and 10 'bonus levels') + 15 local co-op levels (with a horizontal split screen as seen in one of the screenshots).The goal in each level is to collect 3 items and then find your way to the exit. To reach that goal, you'll need to take blue and red boxes from one point to another. Sometimes you'll need to aim and throw the boxes to their destination. You'll be jumping from platform to platform, sometimes switching your 'polarity' mid-air. Your polarity is a red or blue glow that allows you to pass through force fields of the same colour but prevents you from falling through force fields of the opposite colour. This makes for some interesting mechanics. Unfortunately, it also means that Polarity sometimes becomes a twitchy game when you quickly need to push several buttons  during one long jump or during a series of short consecutive jumps.Graphics, sounds and other issuesThe graphics are very basic. They aren't pixel graphics but nonetheless they look quite pixelated when seen up close. However, they serve their purpose here and the 'laser-look' makes up for a lot. I don't just mean the force fields that are made of lasers, but the platforms have a laser-like edge and the walls and the ceilings have laser-like lights drawn through them, too. This livens up a bit what would otherwise be very bland graphics.The music is subtle. Actually, the music is hardly noticeable. Its volume is too low. You'll need to turn up the volume of your speakers a lot to actually hear it, which makes for tons of fun when another sound pops up, for example a new incoming message, which may startle you and everyone who's in the room with you. There are little options in the game's menu: you can adjust camera sensitivity and switch music and sound effects on or off. When launching the game, you do get the standard Unity pop-up allowing you to change the resolution, select the overall graphics quality and toggle windowed on or off.Controls feel a bit clunky from time to time. I used an Xbox controller because that seemed the logical choice for a platformer, but maybe keyboard and mouse makes for a smoother experience, I don't know. A strange thing happened to me when using the controller: when moving the camera left, it kept turning left even when I didn't touch the controller anymore. I had to tap the camera to the right for it to stop. The same thing did not happen when turning the camera right, and this problem doesn't occur when I'm playing other games, so it's a weird bug in Polarity. When trying to find a solution for this problem, I came across posts from people complaining about much worse involuntary movement of the camera and even of the player's avatar, rendering the game pretty much unplayable. So Polarity is not a fully polished game, it seems, and technical difficulties are not out of the question.A word about Steam's extra featuresPolarity has 6 Steam Trading Cards. You'll get 3 just for running the game.Most of the 10 Steam Achievements are awarded for completing a number of levels successfully. The remaining few achievements are a bit more creative but are easily attained. If you don't have a co-op partner, you can complete the first co-op level by yourself to get that achievement relatively quickly, but you'll be left with two incomplete achievements: one for finishing all 15 co-op levels and one for finishing all the levels of the game, unless you want to take both avatars through each level, one by means of a controller and one by means of the keyboard and mouse. Verdict: it's not as good as PortalA lot of critical reviewers dislike Polarity because it isn't as good as Portal. And they're absolutely right! Moreover, the publisher of Polarity brough the storm of criticism on themselves by mentioning the name Portal in their game's description. Even though they don't compare their game to Portal (on the contrary, they say their game is the best puzzle platformer since Portal, which means they recognize they can't top Portal, but they do claim their game is better than all the puzzle platformer games made after Portal), they should have known just mentioning the name Portal would mean endless comparisons between the two games, a comparison they could never hope to win.But I'd like to judge Polarity on its own merits. In that case, I have to say I enjoyed Polarity considerably more than I found it frustrating, which means a positive verdict in the end. But I do have to stress that Polarity is not worth its full price. I mean, it's the same price tag as Portal, a game of which even the publisher of Polarity admits it is a better puzzle platformer. You should consider giving Polarity a chance only when it's on sale at -75% or better, and lower your expectations accordingly.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												A nice puzzle game that kind of feels like Portal without portals. There's stuff like launch pads, cubes that activate certain moving objects and open doors, a mechanic that allows you to pass and walk on different types of platforms and a co-op mode. The levels are all very well made and will definitely require some thinking to complete them. Each level has 3 'data fragments' which are optional to collect to unlock certain bonus levels. These fragments are often very easy to obtain, but some of them are very well hidden. One thing that I should mention is that the game is not very big (even together with the bonus levels) and I could not get the co-op missions to work. It's definitely worth the money though, had great fun playing it!

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
Product received for free
												This game won't start from Steam, so I had to gather 5 minutes spamming the Play button to write this.When I launched it from the exe, the game looked promising.The mechanics featured in the tutorial was really novel.And that's where it ends.It's in the name of the game.The game is called Polarity, for crying out loud.You're meant to get around by switching your polarity.Yet, in the first 10 or so levels after the tutorial level (couldn't be bothered to count), I can probably count the number of times the mechanic was used ON ONE HAND.If that isn't enough, the graphics are lacking and the physics are wonky.Level design is wanting too; the first few levels were okay, but after that it becomes less of a mind-stretching puzzle per se (which I assume is the basis for it claiming to be the next Portal) but more of "do you spot this tiny thing at the edge that you have to press", which certainly makes the navigation of maps challenging in an annoying way.Also, attempting to fling cubes across the entire map is just plain disgusting, and takes way too much trial and error. I can only imagine that's the reason for the cube reset button. More disturbingly, it's the most efficient way to place cubes on a receptacle. If randomly spamming cubes at different angles and hoping one gets caught by the receptacle is the best way of putting a cube on the receptacle, I don't see why I should invest any more of my time in this game.Certainly wouldn't recommend buying for anything more expensive than the 98% off sale price.(I also wouldn't recommend buying it for the sale price since it's such a terrible game, but you get card drops if you actually manage to start it up.)

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												A short, light, relaxing puzzle game that you can finish in one sitting. It's actually refreshing to see a puzzle game that doesn't overdo it -- a lot of them will have 50, 100 levels that ramp up in difficulty and confound you for hours of play time but not give much reward. Polarity doesn't either, but it's just simple enough that it never becomes tedious or repetitive. Sometimes you just want a snack, not an eight-course meal. There's not quite enough here to justify the full price tag, but it's a great sale pickup.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												In short, fun little Portal-wannabe game worth 0.19€ bought on sale.That being said, the game has several problems:Bugs - There are quite a few bugs, main issue there is clipping and disappearing cubes through floor or walls when not being careful (had this happening several times in coop). Other annoying bugs include auto dropping cubes when coop partner dies, random rotation of camera when using gamepad (Xbox 360 controller in my case) while pressing nothing and no end game screen for coop campaign  (there is normal "Next" button which does nothing so you don't know if it's broken or what's happening)Difficulty - Sadly the difficulty is almost none, all "puzzles" are very straight forward requiring almost no thought. I'd definitely wouldn't call it "demanding all of your wits and reflexes" as devs do.Coop - It's advertised as multi-player game but it only contains local coop (which wasn't problem for me but it might be for others). Included coop campaign isn't really coop for most of the parts, there are few moments where two players must interact with each other to finish the level but otherwise it's mostly one doing all of the work while the other is waiting for partner to open the road for him (being a burden in short).Length - Both coop and single-player campaign takes only around an hour each.This might sound like very negative review but in fact it really isn't. Thought there are issues with the game, they aren't game-braking. I still enjoyed playing coop with a friend and can only recommend it for this next-to-nothing price. However paying full price would most likely change how I perceived the game.

												the programing and graphics are pretty basic. they'd pass for some games, but there are some bugs (in multiplayer i could use the "drop" button to make the other player drop their block) and the models were really lazy. the player model is a block with another smaller block on a stick. the menu is worse.but the real problem is the level design. quite frankly, it plays like a free flash game. the puzzles are more just a series of obvious steps, as though your not playing through a level so much as moving through it. some of the later levels are a bit puzzling, but they're still really easy.the hidden secrets are usually pretty easy to find too. most of the time they're just behind a pillar or around a corner and you just need to turn around every so often to make sure you didn't miss it. some of the time they aren't even hidden, they're just sitting in the middle of the pathway you're already walking along.the only real hard challenges are the platforming parts, which are well designed but the controlls aren't always intuitive enough for what you want to do.honestly, if i hadn't gotten it on sale for a dollar, i probably would have gotten a refund after playing it for an hour.

content:

												Single player campaign can be completed in 1.5 hours.  There is no plot at all, nor characters to interact with.  There are some solid puzzles which are fun to work around for about an hour or so, but after that some of the more advanced ones suffer from a lack of explanation of puzzles elements.  The music might as well not have been there.  For it's price point ($10 as I write this) I cannot recomend.  All in all this seems more like a grad school project more than a fully produced game.  That does not mean I think this is a bad game though, I was engrossed for a good hour or so, but it needs more to justify itself and its price.There were some elements of the game I didn't play (multi-player/ level editor / bonus levels) but I can't imagine they add a whole lot more to the experience.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
 Not very difficult, but quite relaxing. Buy on a sale!	 More suitable for a younger audience, or simply to relax. The graphics aren't great, but to be honest it didn't take long to get used to. Considering the game has a cyberspace theme, you wouldn't really expect top quality graphics (or at least I wouldn't, anyways...) So they certainly stood out enough to be easy on the eyes for the duration of the gameplay. I haven't tried Multiplayer so I don't actually know what the player model looks like, so in my ignorance i'll assume it has the same minimalistic appeal.The audio for this game, I didn't really notice it. That isn't a bad thing - I knew when something happened, but it was more of a confirmation than actual sfx. It added to the feel of calm under pressure, and aided the relaxing puzzles through what could have been frustrating experiences if it wasn't for one problem......It was too easy. I finished the game (all data fragments) and all the bonus mission in 92 minutes. It was enjoyable, so I would recommend at a low price, but it certainly wasn't something that I had to struggle to understand the solutions. It took a few attempts to actually do some of the solutions, granted. Some of that was because of a slight issue with physics/momentum that I wasn't expecting. If you are on a moving platform, you will continue to move in that direction as you jump off it. This means that instead of jumping towards what you are looking for you have to account for a slight air drift. Which, again, wasn't difficult to understand, just wasn't as expected initially.I don't know if this game was supposed to be for a younger audience, or if I am better at this game than others. Personally I felt like the bonus missions should have been part of the main missions, but if the game was meant to be a little easier I can understand why the difficulty would be at a mismatch in that situation. There were 22 levels (including bonus levels) for Singleplayer mode, and I assume 15 for multiplayer - given there are 3 fragments per level and 45 set to CoOp mode. All the same, I was sort of expecting more challenging puzzles, but I didn't dislike the experience up to the end goal.I doubt this game would get a great deal of re-runs. The base price is not worth the content in my opinion. That being said, I got this game around 90% off (maybe more) and I certainly think this game would be worth it at a discounted value. I have seen this game on sale many, many times. So long as it is half price or better, I would say go for it. As it stands, however, my view is that the game should be around four times longer, with much more challenging rooms in order to justify the retail value asked. Or maybe include a level editor and allow workshop support, but that is likely above the developer's skill level judging by the content provided. Again, not a bad thing, as I in no way disliked the levels that I played, I just don't think that there is  enough  content provided...PS - Technically, you can get this game at such a steep discount that you could sell the trading cards and make money, though if you are into that kind of thing you'd already know that without reading this review.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												Honestly I feel pretty good about this game, however there are a few things I should mention for anyone who is considering purchasing this game.1) The levels are really easy, as you can see, (not sure if I have played more after this) I have played the entire single player campaign in 1 1/2 hours.2) The concept is interesting, but needs a lot more work, more elements in the standard campaign would be nice, instead of relegating everything to the bonus levels.3) Large areas, very little story, no voice work.  This game feels great for what I purchased it at for $0.50.  Now seeing the price at $11, it feels very lack luster.4) Co-op is couch co-op, no online co-op.  Which was confusing when I saw "multi-player" which I assumed meant online play, there is none available, so it was really mistagged.5) There are a few levels in which it is required that you die to progress, this came to a shock for me the first time, every time after it became the solution to harder puzzles.Final verdict, if you are purchasing this game while it is on sale below $11, then get it, its a good quick game to try and test your brain on, however if your not, consider waiting.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Pros: -interesting visual style-the polarity mechanic is well implemented-great, immersive atmosphere-creative puzzlesSwings (whether it's a pro or a con is subjective):-heavily, *heavily* inspired by portal-HEAVILY inspired-HEEAAVVIILLYYCons: -Graphics are somewhat dated-somewhat jittery, even at 120FPS on a 144Hz G-Sync monitor, either due to poor optimization or locked V-Sync-Jump button often just plain doesn't work, even on straightaways-sells itself a little bit too much with that description there...Nitpicks:-There are points at which you need to sprint, jump, switch polarities in midair to pass through a lazer grid, then switch polarities again to land on the below platform, which can be awkward, given that you need to press both the W and Q keys at the same time-The game seems to be programmed so you can't jump when you're in contact with a wall, and the edges of platforms seem to be rendered as walls, so, if you cut a jump too tight, you won't even jump at all, making the timing a bit more pixel-perfect than likely intended-At one point, when I fell off, the game spawned me backwardsOverall:If you can find it on sale, get it. As is, it's not worth $20, but it has potential, and hopefully, with future updates, everything can be smoothed out.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												And I thought the first Portal game was short...○ While this does have some nice ideas and a few puzzles took me a while to figure out, it's way too short. I 100%ed (all collectibles and achievements) the whole singleplayer part of it in less than an hour and a half.○ It's also pretty buggy, I managed to clip out of the map through a wall once without actively trying to do so.○ The movement feels really tedious - you can get stuck on a 1 inch step and have to jump in order to traverse it. The collision detection of jumping platforms is a pain, too, among other things.○ Then there's the thing with some of the puzzles... You know, in a puzzle game I like the idea to be "spend some time figuring out what you have to do, then do it" whereas here it's often "see what you have to do right away, then spend 5 minutes trying to pull it off with the dodgy physics system and clunky movement".○ Some gameplay elements don't add anything to the challenge of the puzzle itself, they merely serve as a layer of hogwash that can foil your efforts at any point (I'm mostly talking about the moving lasers).○ A couple times I didn't get any hints on newly introduced mechanics (e.g. rotatable jump pads or cube colour changing portals) so I wondered what the hell I'm supposed to do with a blue cube and red socket.All in all it's not an awful game but if I had paid the full price for it I'd feel robbed. For the current price of 0.21€ though it'd be a shame not to give it a try.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
Product received for free
												Note: I got this game for free by installing Out There Somewhere, which actually features fun, interesting, and challenging mechanics. Also, I haven't played the co-op stuff yet, but I'm doubtful it's much better than singleplayer.The Good pretty good background music unique core concept (I've only seen color-swap used in 2D) people could make some very interesting user-made levels if user-made levels were a thingThe Bad The learning curve is shallower than a stereotypical blonde. In each main level, the game seems to try to teach you about a gimmick that's specific to the level. One might expect that the level would then have you apply that new knowledge in a more challenging or puzzling room, but... that never happens. The level ends before that.Now, to the game's credit, the bonus rooms are slightly more challenging, although that's like saying getting struck by lightning is slightly less lethal than a guillotine. The game never seems to make up its mind whether it wants to be puzzle-focused or platforming-focused. In some levels, no dexterity at all is required - just figure out when to put which cubes where put the only available cube in the only available switch. In others, however, cubes hardly do anything, and you need to pay more attention to what color you are so you don't fall through the floor. But, it never focuses on developing either, so it's just kind of plain all-around. In some of the levels, it's possible to easily get stuck in a situation that demands you reset the level, losing any progress you might have made, rather than respawning at a checkpoint. Fortunately, the levels can all be beaten in about 2 minutes, so you don't miss out on too much. The physics engine can be pretty weird when dealing with the color cubes, and with moving platforms. Cubes sometimes get stuck in walls, and a few times got stuck in a spawner, only becoming dislodged when I rapidly clicked in its general direction and it popped out of a separate wall entirely. Cubes do not seem to interact with moving platforms. A strange amount of emphasis is placed on throwing accuracy. Polarity compares itself to Portal, which does not have this odd and rather inconsistent mechanic because portal shots travel in straight lines, whereas Polarity's cubes drop off at a rate never quite what you expect. A couple of the gimmicks are never explained. In the level that introduces color-changing fields, nothing draws you to the unassuming small gap that looks a bit like a wall. Additionally, you have no way of knowing other than sheer luck that the launchers affect cubes as well - no previous level required or used that information. In each level, there are 3 green thingies you can collect, for a total of 60 across normal and bonus levels. Of these, two, maybe three require any amount of thought to find them - almost all are either hidden in an unremarkable, useless cove 10 seconds from anything else, or directly in your line of sight. They're not challenges so much as they are errands. GET READY TO HOLD DOWN SHIFT! The player walking speed makes a tortoise look like Speedy Gonzales, and without a toggle, your finger's going to be on that Run button for the entire game. Polarity just feels... unfinished. Like someone had a couple of ideas for a game and accidentally published basic testing levels as the full thing. The story doesn't really have much connection to the gameplay... or relevance to anything at all.TL;DR I sure am glad I got this game for free by playing one that's better in every way, because I wouldn't pay $0.99 for this, let alone ten bucks.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												This is a speed-running, platformer puzzle game.  Each level has some endpoint you must reach by using color-coded switches and platforms.  (The colors are supposed to indicate opposite polarities.)  Each level also has 3 collectibles to find, which are always positioned in some out-of-the-way location to increase your completion time.  Surprisingly, there is no reward nor punishment related to how quickly you finish each level, so there's not really a point to actually try for the speed-running.  The puzzles are okay, but certainly not comparable to Portal as this game's steam page claims.  I found the game moderately enjoyable, but it's very short with less than 1.5 hours playtime (and that includes retrying a most levels for faster times).  The game could certainly use a lot more levels.  In fact, it's perfect for Workshop content, yet there is no level maker.  There are a few bugs with platforms and the small blocks used to activate switches, but nothing game breaking.  I'd like to also play the co-op levels, but the game is sadly local-multiplayer only.Ultimately, I feel like the game failed at nearly everything it set out to do.  You get a handful of mediocre puzzles that you can complete in one sitting, and that's it.  Not a bad game, but not one I'd recommend.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												"Polarity" is a first-person puzzle platformer that's hugely derivitive of "Portal," except that it's:1)  much cheaper (both in terms of price and production value)2)  much shorter (main "campaign" takes about an hour, maybe)3)   much  easier (see #2 above)4)  much not-as-good, frankly.Oh, and there's no jokes...  Or portals, for that matter. There  is  one original gameplay innovation -- you can alternate the ability to walk between red and blue force fields -- but this is so rarely incorporated into the puzzles that it's hardly worth mentioning."Polarity" isn't a  bad  game so much as it's just a deeply unsatisfying one. Taken solely on its own terms as a cheap knock-off, it's made with a certain degree of underwhelming competence.  If you're desperately itching to play a first-person puzzle platformer that starts with the letter "P", and the phrase "cheap but competent knock-off" doesn't scare you away,  and  you've already played through both "Portal" games at least twice, then buy "Polarity" when it goes on sale for fifty cents (which seems to be every six months or so). Do not under any circumstances pay full price for it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												Since I can't really give a neutral review, let me just set this straight. Generally, Polarity is a fun, quick game that is perfect for anyone looking to kill some time. However, it is literally a poor man's version of the Portal games. For a standard price of $9.99 USD, I would definitely not consider this game for a purchase. Why? For around this price range, I rather buy a full, critically-acclaimed, better version of the game  (*ahem* Portal which also has the same standard price of $9.99 USD)  or even chip in some more to purchase the Portal Bundle or the Portal 2 game standalone. This being said, I only purchased this title because it went on sale, at a measly price of $0.19 USD  (yes, that apparently is possible.) To sum it all up, please don't buy it at its full price of $9.99 USD, it's really not worth it. Go look into Portal if you are readily wanting this sort of puzzle game. However, if you really, really,  REALLY  are dying to have it, I highly advise purchasing it only when it goes on sale. Nonetheless, I respect the effort of the indie developers, and will give this game a recommend.  A For Effort, F For Originality, Bluebutton Games.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Polarity is a nice game with some flaws. It's not great, but it's fun to play.The singleplayer levels are short and pretty easy, but still fun. It takes about 1 and a half hour to finish them all including bonus levels. Keep in mind that I got this game as a gift, and I don't think it deserves this much money. Grab it on a sale and you won't regret it.Pros:-Fun singleplayer levels-Portal references-Nice ideas for puzzle mechanics-Despite the easiness, the levels require thinking-Achievements and trading cards-It makes a nice sound when you sprintCons:-(almost) No story-The physics...-Lazy level design, data fragments were poorly placed and in co-op, you don't need a partner to complete a level. You just need them to get to the next level.-Only local Co-op option-The resolution settings. If you have an old monitor, welcome to the world of black bars.-Too short and no workshop support.Additional notes: I normally would consider the idea of being have to collect data fragments to open new levels bad, but it wasn't worth putting it into cons because it was really easy to collect them. It may seem like I didn't like the game, but I did. Polarity is one of those "not so great, yet still fun" games.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												This is basically a platformer game with a few puzzle elements. Polarity mechanics boils down to switching to correct polarity when jumping on colored platforms. Puzzles are trivial and most of the play time comes from traversing unnecessary long distances on foot while constantly holding your "run" key. On a few levels it's literally easier to kill yourself (to reset your position) instead of walking back and forth.There is no narration or plot, aesthetically this game is meh, visually it's unpolished even, from time to time you'll see misaligned textures and z-fighting.Speaking of play time, single player campaign (not counting bonus levels) takes around 30 minutes to beat, but then it asks you to replay it and 100% it to unlock a "Story 02", which is actually a "Thanks for playing" message written on a black screen.I guess I could recommend it if you get it very cheap, but this game also requires you to go through extra hoops to be playable on some configurations. If you're playing on a 120Hz or 144Hz monitor, open your GPU drivers control panel and switch to 60Hz.Apparently if your framrate is too high, game from time to time doens't register jumps and this game has a lot of platforming. You run towards next platform, you press the jump key, hear the jump sound but there is no jump, you just fall off the ledge. This is extremely frustrating. You can't set the refresh rate in game settings. Judging by the forums, someone tried to contact devs about that issue but it's still not fixed. I also hate the mouse acceleration that is there by default but I couldn't find any mouse settings apart from Y invert, which is probably there just for the controller.

Posted: February 10
												Polarity is no Portal but it's a solid game in its own right. I see that some are complaining about its simplicity and its brevity but honestly, those are some of the qualities I like about Polarity. No puzzle is so challenging that it leaves you scratching your head. Each puzzle can be solved in a span of 1 to 5 minutes. It makes the game more of a relaxing experience, whereas, Portal could be relaxing or it could be hectic.There's little to no story in Polarity but I really enjoyed the TRON-esque asthetic the developers went with. Overall, I found myself enjoying this game and for the price that I paid while it was on sale (I think 99 cents?), I ain't gonna complain about it being short or whatever...If you like puzzle platformers and you see this one on sale, pick it up.8/10

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												(PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS IS ONLY A REVIEW FOR THE SINGLEPLAYER CAMPAIGN. I'LL EXPLAIN WHY LATER IN THE REVIEW)I don't know what I expected for four dollars (though I got it for 19 cents), but apparently this isn't it.GameplayIt felt way too short, but that was probably just because they kept repeating the same puzzles/parkour stunts over and over again, such as when you have to switch polarity in midair to stay on/avoid the platforms/lasers. There were about 5-7 actually unique puzzles.Also, the mechanics weren't being used enough, such as the on/off switch and the rotation buttons. Even the polarity was mostly just used for either the midair-polarity-switch stunt or fields that blocked certain cubes.Plus, the data fragments were placed in awkward positions and it didn't feel like they had anything to do with the puzzle at hand. 3/10EnviromentThere's no real plot aside from being informed that you are hacking into some super important company (although it doesn't look like you're in cyberspace). We are never told what this company is, what they do, or why we need to hack into it.The scenery never changes, either. We aren't showed where we are before we take up the offer, we aren't shown how we get transported into cyberspace, we aren't shown how we get beamed out once we finish the mission, and we aren't shown where we are when we get the massive supply of credits.And it's completely clean with no props or broken walls anywhere, despite the numerous video games that showed us that messier was better. Portal had the famous Rattmann dens, Portal 2 had the facility beat up and destroyed in many of the chambers, Gateways had the laboratories broken into by a messy criminal, etc. And just because it's in cyberspace doesn't mean you can't make some areas briefly be replaced with nonsense code before automatically repairing itslef or have the lights take a while to turn on.Final note: There's just too much black and dark gray on the walls, floors and ceilings, especially in the later levels of the game and the bonus levels. Wouldn't hurt to make it half-light, half-dark like Portal. 2/10Co-opI do not have any friends who are willing to come over to my house just to play Portal 2 minus the portals. Either way, I don't think it would be that much of an improvement. 2/10The store pagedoesn't contain that much content from the real, finished game. As a matter of fact, from the looks of it, the prototype was better than the real thing. It contains some final levels with a better balance of dark and light, and one level that was two from the finished product put together.The description contains numerous flaws. "One of the most fun puzzle/platformers since Portal." is a little bit too egotistical and not very true. "Polarity takes it to the next level, demanding all of your wits and reflexes." is hardly true at all. I finished all of the singleplayer levels with all of the fragments in around 114 minutes, and I only stumbled across 2 levels that required reflexes (along with the numerous midair-polarity-switch stunts) and they were pretty easy. "Full-featured local co-op campaign." I am not sure about. 2/10OverallThis game is hardly worthy of your money, even if it's only nineteen cents. 2/10

Posted: November 16, 2015
												Interesting little puzzle game, sort of a Portal with aethetics more akin to Tron 2.0. Not too terribly difficult; most levels only took me a few minutes. Good distraction for a couple hours; I picked it up as part of a four-game bundle for about a dollar, so in terms of money-per-unit-entertainment... I'd say it was worth it. (Had I spent its current "full price" this review would have a very different tone.)The backstory is that you are, um, hacking some computer system or something? The backstory is completely irrelevant, and can safely be ignored.The game has a bunch of interesting mechanics (a switchable "polarity" that lets you pass through walls or lasers; red and blue cubes for activating switches; jump pads of various sorts; etc)-- it's unfortunate that the game is so short, since it seems like there are some missed opportunities there.The "co-op" mode is local split-screen only (not online, oddly). I was able to work through it (as one person) with a keyboard and a gamepad; there's little in the co-op campaign that requires active participation by both players simultaneously. That could have used a bit more work.

Posted: June 12, 2015
												Polarity is a 3-D first person physics puzzle game with the core mechanic of switching "polarities" to progress through the level. In each level there are three data pieces located in hidden or hard-to-reach places that you must collect to finish the game. If you were a fan of the box-juggling of Portal, this game has plenty, as most levels requires you to carry, throw, and place boxes on buttons. It's a fun little game whose biggest issue is the little. The game is fairly short, and I was able to beat the "story mode" in less than an hour, half of which was going back through the levels to collect all the "data" I missed due to tricky placement. New mechanics are barely added in this short amount of time, meaning each level feels roughly the same. The puzzles weren't challenging enough to help the length, and the story mode is barely a story. The game doesn't really use its core mechanic to its full potential, and it really seems like just a box-and-button puzzle game rather than something fresh and new. The aesthetic is nice.If you do get this game, get it during one of its sale periods where it goes down to like 19 cents. I do recommend it because it is a nice puzzle game, but it's not all there.

Now, the puzzles aren't super hard and don't require much skill but the graphics are pretty while the actual gameplay is solid and fun. You get to pick up cubes to throw them in what I will call "trigger boxes" which gives a portal feel and that's really neat as well. Overall this is worth picking up and definitely worth spending some time on if you even mildly enjoy puzzle games.

Posted: December 26, 2015
												Polarity is the poor man's Portal, but perhaps that's being a bit unfair to Polarity; it IS its own game in its own right. It doesn't have an incredibly engaging story to it (in fact, save for a short text introduction at the beginning of the game, there's no story to it at all), but at the same time it doesn't really need one. The objective of each level is to use colored cubes to activate corresponding gates and switches to get to the end-level warp while collecting data fragments.HIGHS: --Gameplay is fun and engaging, albeit a bit bare-bones.             --Bonus levels and Co-op campaign add much needed replay.             --The music (or I should ambience) is soothing without becoming repetitive. Accompanied with the easy-on-the-eyes visuals, the game is actually quite calming (in the good way).LOWS: --The levels aren't incredibly challenging. They're enough to make you think, but none will really stump you or leave you stuck.            --There's a couple important details the game neglects to inform you about. For example, later in the game you'll encounter yellow gates that, turns out, change the color of whatever cube passes through it. An attentive player would be bound to figure this out on their own eventually, but the more casual player may not be so quick to catch on (especially when the FIRST none-red/blue gate you encounter without being informed kills you).            --The game is FAR too short, especially for the asking price of $10.99 (The single player campaign can be finished in less than an hour, even if you're not the greatest at puzzle games). The game could've, and SHOULD've, been much longer; especially with the multitude of potential puzzles the aforemention yellow gates can bring to the table.BUY or BYE: I say buy, especially if you're a big fan of the Portal series or puzzle games in general. Polaris is not worth the default $11. A good default price would be $5 (perhaps $9.99 at the most), but certainly not $11. HOWEVER, it IS a fun puzzle game that should be experienced, and for the current sales price of $0.54, you can't go wrong!
