Posted: May 24, 2015
PresentationPolarity is like a simpler and shorter version of Portal, but that doesn't necessarily make it a bad game or a relentless copy of the game which obviously inspired it, as there are plenty of concepts and ideas that make this title stand on its own. To begin with, there are no actual portals, as the game relies on its blue-red polarity concept to solve puzzles, allowing you to change your polarity in order to pass obstacles and reach otherwise inaccessible areas. As that alone would become boring, companion cubes show up just at the right time to throw in the extra element that allows certain levels to present you with challenging puzzles, without over-complicating them to the point where you don't know what to do next. Cubes, just as yourself have polarities as well, however their polarity can only change in special areas, forcing you to use what you have at your disposal in order to solve puzzles, and since you can only summon a limited number of cubes, the solution will always pop up once you've exhausted all other options, making puzzles challenging, but not unsolvable. Unlike Portal, Polarity doesn't have a background story, and there is nothing to tie in one level to the next one, making your entire adventure feel without purpose, especially since the single player campaign can be finished in less than an hour.Rating: 6.5GameplayThe gameplay is simplistic and accessible to anyone, as it only requires basic character and camera movements and control buttons for switching polarity and interacting with cubes and other objects, but aside from that logic is the only tool you need in Polarity. Puzzles are challenging, but they never get to the point where they become hard or unsolvable without consulting a guide, mostly because the game will be over before the level design reaches that point. There are a lot of interesting features packed in the final levels, and there was definitely room for a lot more afterwards, but unfortunately none of those features reached their full potential, as the level design remains basic, even when there are more elements involved, as the solution will always be obvious once you take a look around you. The polarity switch is the game's greatest strength as it creates opportunities for clever and unique puzzles, but once again this feature never goes beyond that basic gate, making it feel unused in most cases. There are some interesting puzzles to have fun with, but even so it shouldn't take you longer than four minutes to solve each one, as you will always find the solution to each one once you've failed on your first attempt and realize the answer is the other way around.Rating: 6GraphicsThe game looks okay for what it is, however even with the test chamber look inspired by Portal, there was room for a few details to differentiate one level from another, but in this case all the levels look similar and the only thing to set them apart one from another is the placement of the objects required to solve the puzzle. The visual effects are basic, and once again for what this game is, they do the job, even though in certain areas better effects would've made a difference in the sense of power the game tries to give you by interacting with its objects.Rating: 5.5AudioThere are no voices in here since there is no background story, narration or characters, leaving the entire experience up to the level design and the puzzles, but the lack of such things only makes the game seem shorter than it already is. The sound effects are basic and repetitive, as you will still hear the same interaction sounds over and over again; the soundtrack is limited and even though it is in theme with what the game offers, you will eventually grow tired of hearing that same tune all the time.Rating: 4ExtrasApart from the single player campaign, there is a Co-Op campaign which consists of a collection of levels designed for two players and a Bonus campaign which can be accessed once you've finished the main missions; all that added up and you've still got only 2-3 hours worth of content.Rating: 6.5VerdictPolarity is a fun game to play if you fancy the genre, however don't expect this to have anything else to offer besides its gameplay concepts, and even with that in mind there is not much to play; after all, this is a 5€ title.Rating: 5.7Check out the full review and a lot more about Polarity at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=338

Posted: May 9, 2015
												The game says it collects coop data, but there are no chickens anywhere and it doesn't look like Farmville at all.What is the CIA trying to pull here?No mouse sensitivity setting. With a gaming mouse, I have to switch dpi whenever switching between 3D and menu. I am beginning to appreciate that my mouse has dedicated buttons for that. Set it to 400 dpi, Windows to 1/11, still too fast.Same with sound volume. Too low, and not adjustable.Autorun would be very helpful, too.Dropped the cube on an arrow plate - couldn't pick it up again. A little bug I guess.One time the cube moved to me in slowmotion when picked up.One time I threw my cube against a wall and it vanished in it. Another little bug. (They're so cute. :3)One level had a fail condition, requiring a restart. Not a big deal. Just seems like unintended design.Rotation arrow buttons are the wrong way. The button showing clockwise rotation turns the whole room counter-clockwise. Bit confusing at first.Progressive complexity, without becoming actually more difficult. A generally easy-difficulty game for those who don't like their head to go up in smoke. Although it's also so non-exciting that it can become difficult to find motivation in the more complex levels.Jumping is nicely controllable, even in mid-air. Since there are jump-timing puzzles, this is very good. A bit bothersome maybe that you get stuck at very low edges and need to jump there, but you can just adjust to that.Menu navigation is a bit tedious with no rollover and no good visual selection indication.Barefoot walking sounds, yet jumps and landings sound like shoes.The 'story' is lackluster even for this game, especially because the 'ending' text abruptly goes out of character. They could just as well not have made a story at all if they don't put any passion into it.A game should be easy or short, but not both. This is  of acceptable length if you play all the content types. But cooperative mode I found bothersome, because player 2 can only be controlled with a game controller, and while I have that (otherwise not playable it seems), controlling your avatar using a game controller is a challenge in itself, especially if you're not used to it.Since I got this with heavy discount - 19 cents, I didn't consider it a bad investment. Especially since a foil card dropped, hah.

Posted: November 16, 2015
												Interesting little puzzle game, sort of a Portal with aethetics more akin to Tron 2.0. Not too terribly difficult; most levels only took me a few minutes. Good distraction for a couple hours; I picked it up as part of a four-game bundle for about a dollar, so in terms of money-per-unit-entertainment... I'd say it was worth it. (Had I spent its current "full price" this review would have a very different tone.)The backstory is that you are, um, hacking some computer system or something? The backstory is completely irrelevant, and can safely be ignored.The game has a bunch of interesting mechanics (a switchable "polarity" that lets you pass through walls or lasers; red and blue cubes for activating switches; jump pads of various sorts; etc)-- it's unfortunate that the game is so short, since it seems like there are some missed opportunities there.The "co-op" mode is local split-screen only (not online, oddly). I was able to work through it (as one person) with a keyboard and a gamepad; there's little in the co-op campaign that requires active participation by both players simultaneously. That could have used a bit more work.

Posted: January 7, 2016
Polarity  - A first-person puzzle game in the vein of Portal.****Arbitrary Number Rating****||//////||////||__ 5.5/10 __||\\\\||\\\\\\||The descriptions seem to make Polarity out to be a challenging puzzle game that is made for fans of Portal who want more. Beyond being a first-person puzzle game with discrete puzzle rooms that require you to unlock switches to progress to the next puzzle chamber, the comparison between Portal and Polarity is miles apart. The game isn't exactly challenging and the narrative is pretty bare and forgettable.Although portals are absent, Polarity does introduce some original, although very simple new mechanics to add to the "drop off box at checkpoint to open door" puzzle genre, mostly relating to the "Polarity" of the player. You switch your polarity between Red and Blue to get through shields and jumping platforms. Also included are co-op and competitive splitscreen modes, but I did not try those out. #Very short and easy, with little replay value. Great for those who are hankering for a small, small dose of Portal-like puzzle gameplay. Pick it up when discounted at 90%, not worth otherwise.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												Polarity in a sentence: Polarity is a first-person puzzle/platforming game where you, well, solve puzzle and... yeah.That was Polarity in a sentence (And a half, I guess). Now, it's time for the real review.Basic Info:Polarity, greatly inspired by Portal, is a first-person puzzle platformer. You can play singleplayer or multiplayer. Either way, they're the same kind of puzzles.List of Basic Uses:-Cubes: Used to activate switches, platforms, laser walls, etc.-Polarity: You switch your Polarity (Your color, some say) to jump onto colored platforms, or to get through a laser gate without dying.-Gold Lasers, A.K.A. Color Changing Lasers: These are lasers that you can throw cubes into to change their color from either red to blue, or blue to red.-Data: These are collected to unlock more levels throughout the game and eventually unlock the bonus stages. There are three per level.Other Notes:This game is completly Xbox 360 controller compatible without any configuration needed. There is also a split-screen multiplayer that has its own campaign.Story:Honestly, Polarity doesn't really have a story at all. However, you can peice together a basic story from what you're told.You're a hacker trying to break into one of the greatest firewalls in the world, trying to collect data so you get your reward that was promised to you by an unknown person/thing - 10,000,000 Credits.Gameplay:Polarity has you jumping from platform to platform, switching your Polarity (Or, some may call, your color) and carrying and throwing cubes everywhere. What I'm trying to say is that you may have to get through a  red  laser gate, so you have to switch your polarity (Which, by default at the begining of every level, is blue) to, obviously, red. That's different with platforms, however. With platforms, you must switch to the  opposite  color to get across, which leads to switching polarity in mid-air. What I'm trying to say is that your Polarity and ablility to work with cubes is all you need to beat the levels.Polarity has 14 levels in singleplayer that are not too tough at all, but can actually be a bit fustrating for reasons such as "Crap, put the cube in the wrong spot - Oh, there it goes. Bye cube. Just gotta run back to the other side of the map again to get a new one..." Most of the levels are short, but every now and then, you'll notice repeating concepts in the levels. For exaple, you may have just completed a level where you had to through cubes into switches and now, you're throwing cubes into color changing lasers and then putting them in switches. May not  sound  similar, but once you play, you'll know what I mean. That, however, is not too much of an issue.Upon getting every Data Crystal in the singleplayer campaign, you unlock the 10 bonus levels. These levels are just  barely  harder then the normal campaign, which is easy once you get the hang of how things work.Difficulty... That's an issue. This game isn't hard by all means. It's just fustrating. Like in my example above, you can easily throw your cube the wrong way or just barely miss the button for it and *POOF*! It's gone. You'll have to go back and get a new one. Anyways, back to difficulty - It's too easy, in my opinion, to be a puzzle game. WAY too easy. The Data Crystals aren't even cleverly hidden at all. You can easily get all of those. You'll also find yourself breezing through this game. For example, if you have even the slightest bit of knowledge as to what you're doing, you can get through levels in 1-2 minutes each. The singleplayer campaign (Bonus levels included) may only take you about an hour and a half. That's how short and quick this game is.Ah, multiplayer... I can't say that I LOVE it, but I like it. You and your buddy are robots (Sound familiar much?) and you must work together to solve puzzles similar to the normal puzzles, except this time, it's even harder. This time I mean it. It's not "I GIVE UP!" hard, it's just... Up there, I guess you could say. The Data Crystals can easily be passed without even knowing it, and they're hidden in better spots and actually take you a minute to get them. I would have to say that the multiplayer is better than the singleplayer just because you have a friend with you and you both get to slove the puzzles together.Conclusion:This is a first-person puzzle game that's highly inspired by Portal. Sure, it's not always fair, but it comes through for sure. I would just get this game while it's on sale, as you'll be glad that you didn't waste $5.00 on this. I'm not saying that this is a bad game, it's just I don't see it being worth $5.00. Not everyone looking for a good puzzle game will be satisfied fully, but I still love this game.To conclude this review, I give Polarity a 7/10. It could be better, and it wouldn't be that hard.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												It's quite obvious that this physics-based indie platformer takes heavy inspiration from the game portal, but Polarity doesn't have the complexity it's influence does, just lots of switches and platforms and cubes to pick up and toss. Nevertheless, it is a small, modest game, but still a rather pleasing one. The game has decent graphics and smooth gameplay, although the motion blur was a tad disorienting, but that could be disabled. The instructions are simple, and the game is pretty straight forward. Moreover, the puzzles are insanely basic, they are too easy and lack anything remotely complex or challenging to them. The levels feel particularly identical and short. Furthermore, there's no real story, although that being said, a story isn't always necessary. One thing that really ticked me off was that the multiplayer that it supposedly has, is nonexistent, and you must have a controller along with a keyboard in order to play coop. To sum up, the game is very short and lacks many characteristics that make a game good. Considering that the game is actually eleven dollars and not the 20 cents I paid for it, it definetly isn't worth the money. However, I do recognize that polarity has a very small development team and appreciate the game for what it is.

Posted: July 9, 2015
												Obligatory warning, I really liked this game, but there is way too little content to justify spending 5 bucks on it. Wait till there is a sale and it drops down to 19 cents. I bought this for 12 cents after using the spare change in my steam wallet, and it was totally worth it then. Anyways, lets get started on the pros and cons.Pros:-Graphics look really nice for a game I picked up for 12 cents.-Audio, while repetitive at a few moments during the hour and a half singleplayer campaign, was nice and provided a nice atmosphere for the whole digital hacking heist theme. Not necessarily pro or con:-Many reviews mention Portal as what they were thinking of while they were playing. While it had a unique gameplay idea of polarity switching, it really could've used that mechanic way more than the Portal-esque cube on button style gameplay. Cons:-SO SHORT! Even with the bonus levels, it only took me about an hour and a half, which is why I recommend it only if it's on sale.-Not much of a con, but it was really easy the whole way through. Really could've used a difficulty spike at points.Overall a 8/10 for a game on sale for 20 cents,

												This game is actually fantastic. I bought it on sale intending to challenge it's self proclaimed brilliance as "The best puzzle game since Portal" After having completed the game I can say that while not as good as any of the Portal games Polarity's clever puzzles and addictive collectables kept my interest. It even has a local co-op mode with more puzzles which were fantastic. The only part of the game where I would say it lacked quality was the story in that it doesn't really exist and when it is there it seems kind of cheesy and out of place. There is also a competitive multiplayer mode that is not worth playing at all, but its inclusion did not hurt the game in my eyes. If you are looking for a brilliantly clever puzzle platformer in the vein of games like portal then look no further. It is absolutely worth the price.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Polarity is a short and at times very easy puzzle game. It is in some ways comparable to portal, but without the portals. The main gameplay, at least, is similar to portal. You use cubes on pressure pads around each puzzle room, in an attempt to reach the exit. There is the added task of collecting data nodes, on the premise that you are a "hacker" stealing them from a vault. The story doesn't play too much into this except at the beginning and end of the game.The puzzles themselves are fairly easy. There were a few that I had to think about solving, but most were solvable in less than 2 minutes. For reference: I was even able to complete the co-op levels as a single player, and the entire game to 100% [with all data nodes collected] within ~3 hours.The music doesn't always play in this game, it fades in every now and then with a calming ambient piece. It is very nice, but I don't think there are many tracks that rotate. There isn't any voicing in this game, and beyond text that flashes on screen at the start of the game you are pretty much left to your own devices to figure things out. The graphics in this game are very nice. In some places the shadows look a bit odd, but mostly it looks nice. It has a sort of cell-shaded look, with textures that look fairly minimalistic.To summarise this: Despite peoples insistence to compare this to portal, beyond some similar gameplay mechanics it isn't very similar at all. It isn't overly challenging, but if you want some simple first-person puzzles to wile away an afternoon, this is the game to go for.

												There are 3 major factors that keep me from giving this an upvote.1)  Relating themselves to or even mentioning Portal in the official description.2)  It is 11 dollars.3)  This smidgeon of text right here: 


what the ♥♥♥♥? 
A Screenshot of Polarity
By: Hexie Lambent




If those three things were fixed, I could halfheartedly recommend this as a shallow, brainless diversion for about an hour.  I respect it might have been developed on a low budget, as it VERY heavily presents that fact with its... everything, really.  Sound effects, music, menu, level design, gameplay, all rather amateur.I used very rudimentary gaming skills and logic to very quickly clear the main campaign, and the bonus levels did not interest me.  Again, that's fine, but riding on the coattails of Portal WITHOUT EVEN HAVING PORTALS IN YOUR GAME while charging what I believe to be more than double the fair asking price and then being cheeky about "fooling" people with screenshots... leaves a very sour taste in my mouth.All things considered, I bought this a while back for 19 cents, thankfully.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												After 100% completing the single-player campaign (including the bonus levels) I do not recommend this game and here's why.-The puzzle designs are lazy and linear. I wouldn't even classify them as puzzles as they don't really get you thinking.-Even though the main mechanic of the game is that you can change your polarity, you suprisngly don't use it that often.  Not as often as you should. It felt like most of the puzzles used the cubes more than the core mechanic, and that got   boring fast.-Cubes. The physics weren't the best and elevators were the worst. Rising platforms (Elevators) would have a circle pad  in the middle to put a cube on to raise the platform. However if you fell off the platform you could not get the cube  off, so you'd have to go back to the beginning and reset the cube back to it's orginal position, and like I said before  since the puzzles revolved around them you would have to do whole entire levels again just because you fell.-At first I thought the data crytals were supposed to be secret, optional objects you would find in levels. But the hiding   places are so stupid. On one level there's a data crytal in a corner not being blocked by anything, just out in the open.  Another level has two of them next to each other. Because of how poorly they are hidden and that the last level requires  you to find all of them, I don't think they are optional.-The story doesn't make sense. You're a hacker hired by a hacking company. What does that have to do with puzzles?  Does the game take place in a computer? It doesn't explain.-At the beginning they explain some of the mechanics but later on whenever they introduce a new object they don't  bother explaining what it does. So good luck trying to find out what to do with a green laser field or a circle ramp.-If you thought Portal 1 was short, wait till you play this. I beat all the levels and got all the data  crystals in less than 2 hours. And it's sad because the game had so much potenial. The graphics were nice and the polarity mechanic was promising.Really, all I have to say about this game is that it is lazy. I give it a 4/10.If you still want to get the game after reading my review, wait for it to go on sale.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												Polarity is a first person logic puzzle game whose concept is vastly inspired by Portal. It has similar mechanics but at the same time it is full of originality. The companion cubes might not be as cute as in Portal, but they’re still present in this game and needed to complete the puzzles. An innovation consists in the ability of the player to switch between two polarities (red – blue) which allows him to run through gates or to jump on platforms, according to the selected polarity.The single player part consists of 14 puzzles that are not too hard to solve, with difficulty increasing each level though. However, even the most difficult levels can be solved in less than 5 minutes each. The 10 bonus levels are slightly more difficult to figure out, but they add new fun features to the game.The coop mode, on the other hand, is quite challenging. The two players must cooperate to solve the puzzles that are much more complex than in single player mode. The levels are bigger, now consisting in multiple rooms. The path to the exit isn’t usually the same for the two players, but nevertheless, they need to work together to reach it. There are places in which timed jumps are needed while trying to grab certain objects at the same time, and these jumps are not easily performed with a controller as compared to a mouse and keyboard setup. Sadly, the game offers only local coop and not online multiplayer, so make sure to invite a friend that can be persuaded to work on those together with you, without him losing his patience. Or even better, maybe you can convince him/her to do those tricky jumps :)Don’t hesitate to buy it, especially discounted, since it is a very fun game!

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												This is a rather interesting puzzle game and a must-have for fans of the genre, where you get hired by a hacking company to solve a bunch of puzzles and infiltrate a system to obtain some pieces of data, needless to say that the story is trivial but that's normally expected from a puzzle game.The puzzles are mildly difficult and only get a bit tricky in Co-op mode.In general, the game's visuals need a bit of polishing alongside some adjustments to the physics involving the player's movement, in addition to that, I had to restart a level from the beginning after dying on the edge of the level because I kept respawning outside of the level.And not forgetting that this game's store page has a Multiplayer tag when it actually only supports Singleplayer and Co-op modes. So, adding a Multiplayer feature would be great instead of just having the tag...But regardless of its flaws and after completing the game, I'd surely recommend it while hoping that the dev/devs will release some updates to both fix the issues mentioned above and to probably add more content to this nice game.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												I completed the single player game (bonus levels included) very quickly, getting all possible single player achievements along the way. Almost the entire time I was wondering when it would get harder. It never did. I never had to think too hard to solve the rooms, or look in obscure corners to get the data fragments. When I finished the game I was left feeling like it had never really gotten started. If you’re after an easy, relaxing puzzler that won’t take all day or require a lot of thought, this is very much for you. I would suggest waiting for it to be on sale (I got it for $0.19, and I can’t express how glad I am I didn’t pay $5 for it).The game itself looks decent enough. There are little issues here and there, like some minor Z-fighting in spots, and in one level there is a doorway you have to jump through because you get stuck on the lip of the floor otherwise. Nothing game breaking though.Unfortunately I don’t have any friends with this game, so I can’t say anything about the co-op side of it. Overall it’s an okay game, it’s just not one I’ll be recommending to people unless they want a really simple and short puzzler.

Posted: June 10, 2015
												I hate to be the barren of reviewing games i've played but I was expecting more out of this game. When I first saw this on Greenlight, I thought this could be the perfect alternative towards Portal & QUBE (because they don't work on my current laptop) but then I heard that this game was discounted at 96%! Hearing that must of made the game sound really bad but I ignored it. I read the description of Polarity, claiming that it's the most fun Puzzle game since Portal (I even saw a comment on the greenlight page that the dev(s) don't even know what Portal was). Gameplay was just too simple & it lasted only for an hour on my side, the first time playing Portal brought so much confusion that it was thrilling, this game just wanted me to go to sleep. I also looked around the levels set up & I saw so many flaws that it looked like it was rushed from development just to gain revenue. The worst part about it is that it has no decent story, Portal's story was so fasinating that I want to find out more about its connections with Half-Life 2, Polarity states that your a hacker thats trying to access a virtual vault when these levels don't look anything like a firewall. In conclusion, If you want a better puzzle game at a cheap price, Get something that was made perfectly & looks challenging (even if it has mixed ratings). All that it can be used now is to haul trading cards & allowing a short sleep mode onto yourself.

Maybe i am the only one trying to play this game with red switches and the game can't handle that or something i dunno but it's pretty stupid.I bought this game because i like fps puzzle games and since it has the overall rating of "very positive" i just got it because it was in the store for 1,50$. It should be more like 0.50$ or f2p, there are alot of f2p titles that are doing a much better job then this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												This looks like a game with potential, but as it stands I found it pretty unplayable. Jumping simply doesn't work 80% of the time (you hear the jump noise but don't move), which is incredibly frustrating given this is a puzzle platformer. Gamepad sensitivity is also insanely high by default (although this can be turned down in the options thankfully - I had to set it to 0.1 to be usable). Gamepad button prompts are just missing entirely from some tutorial popups. The camera clips as you approach walls in co-op. If these bugs were addressed (and none of them seem like challenging issues) it would be a much more polished experience. I'm happy to change my recommendation if they're fixed in a patch.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
Product received for free
												This game is like a reductive Portal (even their logos are similar, so you can clearly see the inspiration), but also brings something new to the table: you have to switch between the two polarities to be able to pass through gates and jump to platforms, which can require some quick thinking. I enjoyed it, but the co-op can only be played with a controller, so if you don't have one like me (I only have a PS2 one with no adapter), you can't get the last 3 achievements.

content:
Posted: January 23
Portal Except You Pay 99 Cents For It And It's Not Portal And There's No Memes. - An Official Waffle King Review~Find more here.[lordwaffleking.com]When you look through the Steam bargain bin, you're most likely to find♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ copy-paste RPG's, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ "My First Platformer" games from some guy in his garage that thought he'd make it big on Steam with his ♥♥♥♥♥♥ wanna-be Super Meat Boy, or just plain actual♥♥♥♥♥♥ Games that were hastily put together for a quick buck that hardly work but still sell because the trading cards.I bought a ton of these games, because I mean why not? During a Steam sale, this♥♥♥♥♥♥is like two cents. Everyone knows how large your♥♥♥♥♥♥♥is correlates to how many games you own on Steam. But this one game now, I was pleasantly surprised with.It's Portal. Portality. You know. The meme game. The one with the potato and the cakes and the lemons you squeeze in people's eyes.You might not recognize it, but that's only because this is the Walmart brand. This is Great Value: Puzzle Platformer. It has red and blue squares instead of circles. Also they're not portals. But it's like the same exact thing, honey. It's not Lucky Charms but there's a green man on the box. Eat your cereal.Portality barely manages to get by doing what Portal already did so much better. It has the puzzles in there. And there's different colors. Those do something. There's quite a bit of different elements to interact with, actually. Cubes that activate switches and launch pads and all kinds of♥♥♥♥♥♥ The main function, your "Polarity", is purely titular though. You can switch between Red and Blue, and that changes which surfaces you can walk on or pass through. But it's introduced in the first few levels before all-but disappearing until the last few levels, bridged with cube puzzles and♥♥♥♥♥♥While playing through the 20 or so levels that made up the main "story", which by the way sucks♥♥♥♥♥ all I could think to myself was "wow, this game is a cluster♥♥♥♥". A cluster♥♥♥♥ of puzzles. It's not put together the way Portal was. Portal was genius. Portal was all about portals and how many unique kinds of puzzles could be made with them. Everything always came back to using portals.Portality has all these ideas and it just throws them all at you at once. It's like you got drunk and picked up a chick you thought was way hotter at a club, then you wake up with her serving you breakfast in bed and asking what you want to name the baby before she goes dress shopping for your wedding.The feature that the game is named after gets shoved to the side for generic puzzle platforming that struggles to form a cohesive whole.It's a decent play, and has some good co-op features. It's definitely not a bad game. Off-brand Pringles are still Pringles. As long as they're not BBQ-flavored, they're still edible.It definitely passed the time, and there's a decent amount of content as long as you buy it on a sale when it's like 99% off. The game by itself regular price is 10 whole dollars. And that's clearly got to be some kind of elaborate joke, since I finished the game in a day and it wasn't even that great. It's not like it's particularly impressive graphically either. Generic Tron♥♥♥♥♥ polygonal♥♥♥♥♥piece of♥♥♥♥♥There really is nothing but the gameplay itself to look forward to with this game. The presentation is incredibly basic, all the way down to the "Conglaturation! You have completed a great game!" message you get for earning 100% in the main game.There's really no narrative or story to what's going on. You're basically "an elite hacker" that has to "hack things". And all of the cubes you throw around are apparently inside a computer. And when you beat the game it says "thank you for hacking everything". That's it. Whoever wrote the plot to this also wrote Obama's Russian hacker story. There were Russian hackers. And everything is their fault. The end.Portal had some solid lore behind it. This game ain't got♥♥♥♥♥♥ You can't even meme it. There's nothing to meme. There's no decent quotes. And a game without memes is absolutely worthless.Still, considering most of the stuff you find in the Steam dollar bin, it's not too bad. It's definitely functional, it's not 8-bit, and it has something of merit to look forward to, even if it's not exactly done as well as what it's copying.I honestly thought it'd be some cheap♥♥♥♥♥Tetris thing when I started it up the first time. All I saw were squares and thought "well, this must be some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ puzzle game". But it was a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 3D puzzle game. That's nice.As far as ♥♥♥♥♥♥ discount games go, this is one of the best ones. They tried a little. It was good. I know most people only use Steam to play CS:GO, but if you ever think to yourself "hey, I wonder if I can waste a dollar on a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ puzzle game", look no further.

												Entertaining Portal-like puzzle game, without the humour and story line. Only complaints are that the game is a bit short and that it could be a little bit more difficult. Expect a relaxing playthrough with some headscratching though. I personally finished the single player campain and bonus levels in under 2 hours, all 100%.There is a co-op mode and versus mode too that requires the other player to play with a controller, or you can both play with a controller.  It would be nice to also have the option to play co-op online with random people.It would be amazing if this game had a workshop that allows people to create and publish their own levels.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												Short summary of this review: This game tries to be Portal. It isn't Portal. Not by a long-shot.Graphics: Mediocre at best. I'm not a stickler for graphics, but what we have here is a few painfully generic primitives and lighting effects. I wouldn't mind this if the game excelled in some other area, but... well. At any rate, 3/10.Sounds: They don't stand out, but they aren't awful. I somewhat suspect they might be taken from a free sound library somewhere. Nothing wrong with that, but it doesn't really wow me. 5/10.Music: It doesn't make my ears bleed. 5/10.Gameplay: Red block goes on red switch. Blue block goes on blue switch. Press Q to change color and pass through certain walls. As I mentioned, this game is trying to be Portal, but the core mechanic is extremely stilted. There's also the data packets which are hidden in each level, which feel like they belong in an entirely different game. About five levels in, I started thinking 'man, how long is this game???' which is never a good sign. 1/10.Story: An excuse plot, so I won't be taking it into account in the final score. N/AOther notes: Supposedly, Polarity is made for 'experienced gamers'. Each level is about three minutes long, and the only real challenge is finding the switch that you have to throw the cube at. Right.Overall score: 3.5/10. Clearly a first attempt at a game by an extremely inexperienced studio. It showed a little promise at first, but doesn't really do anything interesting at any point.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												Inspired by Portal with its own unique twists.Polarity is like Portal, but with hidden data around each level for you to find, some simple and others are a lot more tricky. The gameplay has its own unique take on the whole orange portal blue portal. You have red and blue, for negative and positive. You must use them in certain ways to progress maps and not die. Its simple gameplay and can be interesting if your lookin for more casual gameplay. No campaign or story, so if you care about that this game isn't for you.The game has bonus levels for when your done the main stages. They add some more difficulty and more mechanics to deal with. The full game can be completed in around 6 hours, more if your going for the full completion. I personally wouldn't spend 5$ on this game, but if you wait for a sale you can get it for 0.50$. Now thats worth.Personal Rating 2/5

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												Pros-Fun-Intresting mechanic-Not entierly straightforwardCons-Short-Not the best music-Polarity isn't implemented as much as I think it could have been.-the floors that kill you are sometimes hard to make out from the ones that don't.OverallI would not spend ten dolars on this game. However I caught it at 90% off. If you can get it at a low price, then I highly recomend it. This game was very fun. The learning curve was decent. There were no times when I had absolutly no idea what to do, but there were one or two times when it took me a minute of looking arond to figure out what I had to do. I like how you can get to the end of a level, but realise you have not colected all the data, causing you to have to backtrack. The one complaint I have about this game is that there are not enough levels. If this game were updated to have many more levels, better music, a slightly steeper learning curve, and some voice acting, I would pay ten bucks for it. But for what I got at $.99, I feel like I got my money's worth.

												This game was alright in single player. It wasn't anything special, and not challenging at all. I burned through the single player and bonus levels with all of the data shards collected in just over an hour. Then we went through the coop in just over another hour with all of those shards. So 100% in around 3 hours. But my main gripe is that the game seemed to have trouble running smoothly in coop. I experienced frame lag all the time, and levels just stopped functioning. I had to play one of the levels 4 times because a platform wouldn't come down even without the power source. If you can get this game for bundle when it's on sale for under a dollar, get it only for Out There Somewhere. That game is amazing, while this is just filler to go along with it. DO NOT BUY THIS BY ITSELF OR FOR FULL PRICE!!!

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												This... this is the perfect type of game for giving an 'eh' or neutral review, but I can't.   It's such a quintessentially human act to try to confine judgments or opinions to pure dichotomies.  Steam.  Anyway!I do think that Polarity - or Portal without Portals, if you like - has a good, if fairly derivative, concept.  Essentially, in lieu of having a portal gun, one can simply change their own polarity, which manifests in either being Red or Blue.  Like colours pass like barriers, and this mechanic (sadly under-used) also applies to the transportable blocks which act as energy keys to platforms, doors and so on.  The player is required to synergise aim, timing and puzzle-solving skills, but the levels never reach that beautiful climax of having length, difficulty and multi-modal challenge in one playable experience.  Things just don't scale up in an intuitive or exciting way; I don't think there are enough mechanics employed  throughout and I don't think the mechanics used have been pushed to their limits.  The relatively short length of the game also contributes to this prosaicness, I think.The total lack of a plot hurts the game.  The data files that players can optionally collect as they journey through the database they're supposedly hacking could have been used to provide background -- why is this data important?  Who is hiring you and why?  Is what you're doing 'right', or does morality even matter in this situation?  Instead, we get a few throwaway lines about earning a bunch of credits and being hired by a company we know absolutely nothing about.   Another perhaps unexpected side-effect of the lack of plot is that, since quite a few levels look similar to each other, they don't really have enough of an identity in their own right.   When the mechanic is used as the Jewel in the Game Crown and it's great, a significant plot isn't necessarily that important... but it wasn't great here and the game really could have used at least more than it had.  The game works.  Movement isn't always smooth, and the camera was somewhat too sensitive in my opinion, but the puzzles all work as intended and they aren't chance-based.  This is good.  The blocks throw fairly well considering there's only one strength setting, although they don't interact at all well with walls and tend to clip poorly.  Having the choice to sprint is appreciated, and the mechanics are intuitive and make sense without needing much explanation -- over-explanation (or the need for it) is a flaw of quite a few modern games.  The graphics and sound are functional but don't excite in their own right.  I'll concede that the relative lack of interesting sound doesn't abjectly cripple the game, and I did enjoy the different coloured hues used in some rooms.  I just got a bit bored of seeing the same tiling in every room and think that even ambient music could have added contouring to the gamescape.  I don't have a gamepad, so I effectively can't comment on the co-op mode.  I wish that the co-op section didn't have achievements, but that's another topic for another day.  In summary, I'd say that it's a good base idea, but it's lacking in finesse, inspiration and length.  When you're selling a game devoid of plot completely on the mechanic and the mechanic hasn't been used to its full potential, it comes off as underwhelming.  It isn't Portal and it didn't grab me, I'm afraid, but it is an acceptable functional, working game.

content:
Posted: February 14
												Basically this game is too short and easy if you are looking for a challenging first person puzzler. There's vibes of Portal and Qube with this red/blue polarity mechanic that can be found in fairly more competent titles like Outland or Ikaruga. Physics can get kinda bugged in places too, primarily cubes that can be moved might fall through moving platforms and get stuck around corners. This game feels more like a proof of concept than a concrete game. 20 very short levels for single player that you can finish in 60 minutes or so. There's some stuff for 2 players too. Its not a terrible game per se, just do not pay the full price for it. I'll give this one a no because it left me craving for so much more.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												Polarity is a short puzzle game which, (Like a lot of puzzle games) has you move cubes from point A to point B most of the time, using some kind of game mechanic.Still reading? Okay!In Polarity you are able to.. Switch polarities which is visualized by you changing between Blue and Red.This leads into some pretty straight forward thinking:Red passes through Red.Blue passes through Blue.This is what most of the puzzle will be based around with you using cubes to power things like jump pads or opening doors to progress and gets a bit trickier as you go further into the game.However here is the reason why I'm giving this a negative review:For as fun and interesting this concept is and with the possiblities it has.. The levels in the game itself are rather easy.This could be because I have played many puzzlers before but I think to even people that are new to games this may be pretty straight forward even for them.That is my biggest issue with that game, Not challenging level design.Though there are a couple more things that irk me:    -The visuals are pretty bad for a game released in 2014. (I did not check if this game existed long before the Steam release)    -There is not much music. Only a couple of tracks in the game that change every level but you'll hear the same track multiple times.    -Some things with the physics don't feel smooth or right.All these things can be negated though if this game was more of a proof of concept.Is this worth 10,99€ or your regional equivalant? Nope.. Though may be fun for a little bit. Also has co-op so you can enjoy a small game with a friend. Get it when it's cheap... Really cheap!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												This game has potential. It could be made into a great game like Portal and Talos Principle if it had a better story (instead of just about 5 lines of text telling you what the story is) and if it was better technically.It is extremely buggy. You'll fall through walls, you'll have the cube you're carrying fall out of your hands for no reason. I played the coop mode with a friend and what he tells me was "it feels like a school project". And he's right, it doesn't feel like a finished product, it feels like some prototype from 2008. There are a lot of strange design choices, from the ugly menus, to some objects behaving really strangely (like the fact that in coop, at the end of every level there are two spots to exit the level, and it won't end the level until the first player is on the left spot and the second player on the right spot, switching spots won't work) (or the fact that you can walk through gun turrets instead of having to dodge their bullets).Still, if you like puzzlers, you could still like it (I liked it, even though I don't feel ok recommanding it since it doesn't feel like a finished product). I don't think it's worth the 10$ they are normally asking, but if you can get it on a sale like I did it could still be worth it, but be ready to have your patience tested, not so much by the puzzles as by the bugs. It took me 3 hours to get through all of it (single, coop, bonus levels), but it could have easily taken me one hour less if I hadn't had to deal with all the bugs and weird design mistakes.

content:
Posted: January 26
Product received for free
												I've only logged .2 hours of playing time on the game but in that time, I felt compelled to write a review.  I cannot believe anyone would not recommend this game.First let me thank EQ Games for the free code out of the blue in my mailbox.  I had purchased on sale two others of their games and I guess this was just a thank you for that.  So far this is my favorite of the three so I can thank them enough.This game reminds me of other puzzle games like Portal and The Turing Test.  Both games I enjoyed immensely (well all 3 since there are 2 Portal games) and this is a very enjoyable and relaxing puzzle game that makes me feel smart once I figure out the puzzle.  So far, the puzzles have been easy and I’m hoping they get harder however even if they don’t it’s worth the cost to play.  (Right now, it’s on sale for 90% off) You may want to wait till it’s on sale to pick it up but still worth it at full price.It even has a nice story line to go along with the FPS puzzle solving that is interesting to start off with.  Maybe not as deep as the previous two mentioned games but still enough to make it worthwhile for the play through.  I look forward to playing the game more and if anything changes for me I’ll be sure to update this review.Oh, and I should mention that so far it seems to have full controller support.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												This puzzle game is very similar to the Portal games, except that in Polarity, you don't have a portal gun, you have the option of changing your "polarity" from blue to red, and red to blue. You must use your polarity changing abilities to maneuver abstacles such as lasers, gates, bridges, and more. For example, depending on the color of a laser, you either can get through it, or you cannot. If it were a blue laser, you would have to change your polarity to blue to get through, and if it were red, you would have to change your polarity to red.The story is a bit awkward, considering this game is an intricate puzzle game with blocks and jumping around, being a hacker trying to get data from a computer network is not a very fitting story.Another thing I wanted to mention was that for me, personally, the pricetag of $15 is asking a bit too much, as I would say $10 or less is a more reasonable price, but since I picked this game up during the 2015 Summer Sale, I cannot complain because I paid 19 cents.Overall, this is a great game, with puzzle elements similar to the Portal games, and other unique elements, but the price is asking a bit too much for what it is, and the story does not fit this game very well.I would recommend this game to anyone who wouldn't mind selling two trading cards for this 19 cent game (when it is on sale).

												so polarity is well just another game that tries to be like portal. however it is fun. now it sort of reminds of this stand alone mod for portal 2 in which you had to go trough test chambers without your portal gun. this is what me reminds me of that. still its a very good game i got it for $0,20 cause it was on sale. the original price might be a little to high for now i mean i didnt even play it for 2 hours and i completed the solo and bonus campaign. so a few things that could improve the game would be:Level editors:if players could create there own levels and share them with the community on the Steam Workshop it would improve the games replay value.Online Co-Op:now there is already a Local Co-Op but for alot of people who dont have a controller for their PC this could be well a let down. so something that could make it better is to have Online Co-Op so you dont need to ask a friend to come over to your house just to play this game togetherBigger story:Honestly this game is short its fun but short so ofcourse much more levels would improve this its just not fun now i finished it. so get this game when its on sale like at the moment (May the 4th (be with you)) its 20 cent. because at the moment its not worth 5 dollars/euros its not.Custimozation:so oke you play as a virus or something like that but that doesnt mean you can't have style. if custimozation was added to the game with unlockable and wearable items it would increase the replay value.I do however recommend it but not until a couple of updates past by and improved it theres still a few bugs and glitches that should be fixed. it honestly still lacks alot but it was made by a small team so i kept that in mind.Final Verdict: A Ghost in The Machine 6/10

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												Wow, this game is bad. In every way. A friend gifted it to me, and after a few levels, I assumed it was some kind of special fundraising game, like a high school kid's senior project that was paying for his cancer treatment or something. Nope. It's an actual attempt at a professional game from a "professional" studio. They're trying to charge $15 for it.Have you played Portal? OK, imagine if you removed the clever basic idea, and substituted a much stupider and boring idea instead. (There are two kinds of walls, red and blue, and you can press a button to switch between one color or the other. Don't forget to press that button, or you won't be able to go through the right colored walls!)Now, remove the quality textures and lighting. Make the controls super muddy and unresponsive. Oh, get rid of all that profession voice action. Actually, get rid of all characters entirely. Yeah, just your third-person camera and some blank walls. That's the ticket!OK now hide the mission objectives behind some of those blank walls so that the player can't find them. No, not the red and blue "polarity" walls, that would seem like you're trying to design a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥puzzle. Just literally HIDE them where they can't be found unless a player goes searching along every single blank wall in the game in hopes of finding a hidden crevice where you stuck one.Voila! You have designed "Polarity"!* Do not, under any circumstances, pay money for this game.* Do not buy someone this game as a gift, even if it's on sale for 90% off, as it is at the time of this writing. It is not worth $1.50.* Do thank your friend for the thought if they buy this game for you (it really was a nice idea!). Immediately delete it from your library. They didn't know what they were doing.-----Stage 8 gets a special mention for exceptionally poor level design. My GOD this game is awful.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												"Polarity" is a first-person 3D puzzle platformer that has a few interesting mechanics. However, it suffers from a number of very visible flaws. The graphics are bland and mediocre. The music and sound effects are poor. The level design is generally simple and dull, giving players little motivation to explore the co-op mode or the bonus levels.Despite the description, this game is a far cry from games like Portal. Overall, I wouldn't recommend this game even if it comes with some very cheap bundles unless you are looking for cheap sources of Steam Trading Cards.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												Polarity is a top down, third person, action, adventure, open world shooter game set in the beautiful country of england. In polarity the main protangonist has to go through endless chucky cheese arcades till he gets to the end of the country. In this game there will be possible gore if turned on in the settings and should be rated M for mature because of the emotional rollercoaster from both the story and art style of the game. The protagonist needs to follow the trails of cheese puff crumbs on the ground to find out who kidnapped his wife and why. The story is full of twist and turns and needs a solid heart yet brave soul to complete those who do not possess these qualitys will not have a fun time playing this game as the the feeling and joy behind the game is hidden in its story which I must say is breath taking. I dont remember a game that has made me feel the same as way as Roblox. What more do you want this game has a very well developed story with a heart breaking ending, graphics that rival next gen titles such as the witcher 3 and is a bang for your buck game.11/10 best game since Backugan Battle BrawlersEdit: Nov 23 2016 - Still best game I have ever played

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												It’s not ground breaking or anything but just OK.Story:You’re a “hacker” that needs to collect “data fragments” in all the levels. Since when did we let Cave Johnson design security systems? IDK. Basically no story.Gameplay:It’s a puzzle platformer. Think portal except portal and more throwing blocks at switches. The puzzles basically involve launch pads, switches, and platforms. There is one component where you switch between red and blue “state?”. The point of this is that you can pass through walls of your own color but not the opposite. This is well used as it also incorporates floors and platforms meaning you have to really think about your next step. There are 11 levels + 10 bonus (why not just make the bonus part of the normal levels idk) so it’s short but It does have coop.Graphics/Performance: (with a 970, 4790K, 16GB of RAM, SSD)The game looks simplistic and the performance remains at 60 solid. The music is not bad as it never gets in the way and isn’t noticeably bad.Final Thoughts:Overall, it’s not amazing or groundbreaking but not that bad.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												While this game has a really creative concept, and i got it for sale in a $1.50 bundle, i still feel that 10 dollars is NOT worth the price for this game mainly due to it's length.It's, as the store description says, inspired by portal and it's futuristic FPS setting, where the mechanic consists of "polarities" (red and blue) that make you interact with different objects in the level, while finding 3 collectibles per level.The thing that ruins it is, first off, the length. I feel that considering how short this game is (i finished the singleplayer campaign 100% in a bit more than an hour) i feel that 10 dollars is not worth the price at all. I'd say that a price tag around $5 would make it better.Second off is the fact that it doesn't make much use of it's main mechanic.As the name implies, the main mechanic is the previously mentioned polarity. However, the game mainly consists of throwing and moving cubes around, with little to no polarity use, wich is dissapointing (I should also mention that polarity only affects 2 objects, lazers and hard light walls).Overall, i think that with a bit of more working around the main polarity mechanic, and making the levels longer and more complex would make this worth the price, but as it is now i don't reccomend getting this normally (On sale, however, it might be a good way to spend an hour or so)On the plus side, TRADING CARDS! (Oh, and i guess the game looks nice, too)

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Short little game with simple puzzles. Even though the maps are clunky made and cubes sometimes dissapear if you throw them at walls, its designed in a way that you wont get stuck. The ideas like switching colours to go through walls and power up ramps that let you choose which way they face have potential, but they dont get complex at all. It has a co-op mode, but only local. Not bad for a game made between work hours, even though it could benefit from the steam workshop.If you played portal and the like you can spend ~1€ to have 1-1.5 hours of cute puzzling.

Polarity is Garbage.I can't emphasize that enough. I played about 2 hours of the game and never made it past the first level. You'll be glad you did. There are plenty of better puzzle games on steam, don't give the developer any more money (It'll encourage him to make more garbage like this).My Rating: 2/10 (Not Recommended; Avoid at all costs)

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												Mysteriously got this for free while registering some other game.  I hear this game gets around and with few achievements, I was looking forward to reviewing this particular title.I'm going to start by saying I respect what this developer was trying to accomplish AND that I enjoyed this title.  Polarity is Portal when you want to portal, but don't wanna portal enough to play Portal.  If GLaDOS wasn't your cup of tea, but you enjoyed the gameplay of Portal, then Polarity will continue your experience, only without portals and with a new polarity mechanic.Play as a nameless hacker and reach the end of the stage via color-cube / switch puzzles based on polarity of the cubes and of your own aura.  The story demands that you collect the collectibles in the stage, but you can enjoy the stages while hunting for the items later if you please.  The polarity mechanic is pretty fun and innovative.What's disappointing about this title, however, is that it's pretty short (About Portal's length of 1.5 hours if you're hunting the items).  There's also the aspect of the lack of ONLINE Coop, which some titles on Steam seem to neglect.  It has local coop, but I feel it's more fun to have an online coop thrown in.  Additionally, the cubes you get can fall through floors/walls and get stuck in cubes/walls.  These cubes have also been able to dislodge themselves from your grip as you land on some platforms.   My final complaint is in the "Lift" jumps.  Jump off a lift and you go propelling in the direction you're headed (moreso than you'd think, which makes it disorienting).In the end, I'll admit that I had fun.  Do I recommend it?  Of course.   Do I recommend it at full price ($10)?  No.  Wait for a sale, bundle, giveaway, or for it to conveniently find its way to you as it's been known to do.  I hear that it's had 99% off discounts before, so try to nab it at that price.  Otherwise, I'd recommend a price of about $1-2.50.7/10  Innovative and fun, but overpriced and in need of polishing.  Not as polished as Portal, but a nice substitute.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
My Experience and ReviewSo I picked this game up cheap- $0.19 and I must say, it's very worth the price. I had a lot of fun with this game, actually. This game is just like portal, except the puzzles are harder (imo) and you don't have a gun that shoots portals. This game focuses mostly on cubes and puzzling. There is no antagonist and there is no protagonist, you're just simply hacking into a system of some sort. What I really loved about this game is how original it is. The only real inspiration found here is from Portal and that's about it. The rest of the game is COMPLETELY original. This game takes more of a fast and jumping around approach and forces you to react quickly, otherwise you may have to restart the level. This game has lots of pros, but some cons as well, but it's kind of expected. Overall, I had TONS of fun with this game, but some of the issues the game had were very frusterating and distracting. It made it harder to play and made my playthrough very tough. Pros- Original game- Fast paced, in-your-face gameplay- No distracting elements (except for a bug I'm going to mention)- Thought provoking puzzles- Soothing and calm soundtrack (It really reminded me of Mirror's Edge for it's serene and mellow soundtrack)- Co-Op Campaign- Great visualsCons- Buggy- Experienced frame rate drops for a few seconds (c'mon, this game can be ran on a potato, it shouldn't have FR drops)- Feels like a game that failed Xbox's market- Unsupported resolutions (1440 x 900 and up isn't supported. I should know because that's my native resolution)Overall Rating/Conclusion7/10 - I'd give it a higher rating if it wasn't buggy and supported better resolutions. Since my resolution (1440 x 900) wasn't supported, I was lowered to 1366 x 768 and experienced a problem with the Steam Overlay and FPS meter. If I used my Steam Overlay key (Shift + Tab) and closed it, the overlay would still be remenicent on the black lines where the game isn't shown (on the outskirts of the game) and same goes for the FPS meter and any notification I get (messages, friends coming online, friends going into game, etc). This bug really upped the "♥♥♥♥♥♥meter" because it was VERY distracting and annoying. If these bugs and issues are fixed, I'd be GLAD to give it a higher rating because I think it deserves a higher one, it just can't be done unless these bugs are fixed.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												A great little game that resembles portal but in much more simpler fashion. It's a bit short and a bit too easy. I played trough the entire thing in 1.3 hour, including bonus levels and all data collected.But I had great fun playing it. It features some pretty cool new concepts, such as rotating rooms and adjustable jump-pads. Overall, it's just a very relaxing game. It is a bit glitchy though. Sometimes cubes can't be picked up from their 'cubeholder', and certain edges can't be jumped correctly. But nothing infuriating or gamebreaking. I couldn't try co-op since it's only local. If online co-op would be added I would rate this even higher.7/10, get this when it's on sale.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												Polarity, a game that is deeply inspired by the Valve TM game Portal, but instead of doing the puzzles, you'll most likely be trying to find the data chunks that unlock levels. This is that kind of game, and the ways you get to some of these are far from me. I have not beat this game, so go and boo on me, but this game has beat me. I can not beat the game due to those damn Data Clusters, wait, sorry, that's from Saints Row 4, data chunks. The game does not want those of us who like gameplay to finish. This game is made for completionist people, who look for the collectibles. This game is not challenging like Portal, it does not have the comedy of Portal, and I know it is an Indie, so voice acting is almost a no, but a game that says it is based on Portal should live up to that, and this game does not. I need to wash my mouth out with a good puzzle platformer to get the taste of this out, so good day to you Sirs and/or Ladies. 3/10         Refunded

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												I saw this recommended on reddit gamedeals a while ago.  Since it was also 20 cents, I figured it was a must buy.  People described this as being like Portal.  I couldn't disagree more.  This is a puzzle game that provides no challenge; it is more walking simulator than puzzle game.  Imagine a walking simulator with no story.  It was so easy it was boring.  The mechanics of the game are not interesting.None of the collectables were hard to get, so I skipped some that were a long distance away because gathering that is not interesting, only tedious.  I reached a certain point where you needed X amount of collectables to move onto the next level, so I stopped playing there.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												From the description of th game:"One of the most fun puzzle/platformers since Portal. Polarity takes it to the next level, demanding all of your wits and reflexes."Uhm... No. Some of the earliest levels of Portal are harder than this whole game. It takes about an hour to finish the single-player campaign. And then, if you have a controller, you may go for local co-op campaign.It's three o'clock in the moring (when I started the game) and I feel sleepy, yet every single level just passes by. You don't have to think much as you come up with solution in the first few seconds while you are running across enormoues empty rooms.You have to collect "data" In order to complete levels perfectly. The only tricky part for that is when you do not look behind some corner as these collectibles are scattered somewhat randomly around the course with no further challenge to getting to them.I bought the game during special offer for 0.99 EUR. Not worth it even for that price. Would go for a refund if I bought it for the whole price of 9.99 EUR.

												Ok, it's not Portal. Nor Portal 2, not that I own either. But its still a great game, that maybe should be bought on sale. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												I played all of the main levels and bonus levels and collected all the data fragments. I did not play the Co-Op campaign.This is a decent first person puzzler - you have a red and blue phases that you can switch between at will, and can pass through or interact with certain items depending on your color.  Move cubes to power devices, change the direction of jumps, and some other environmental interactions.  What's here is pretty good, if a little on the easy side.  But there's only 22 levels, which take 2-3 minutes each to get through.  And the game has very little personality.  Some of the puzzles are pretty creative but a number of the elements don't get utilized enough in the single-player campaign.  And the win screen is pretty minimal.  But all in all, this is a good short first person puzzler.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												It is a weird puzzle game, its like an alpha version of portal.. but without portal guns.The step sounds gets a bit annoying after awhile(feet walking sound)There are nice glitches in the game too.It is a short game and you can play this Co-op (which may look even shorter) This is local Co-op.The characters are really weird. Its a cube on a cube. No legs however just hovering.You can move ur head like u are able to do in minecraft( when u are moving ur camera very quickly in every direction)You have to collect data in each level and you need this to unlock more levels.There is no manual or help in the main menu or options. (like if u have forget to jump or sprint then u can search it to know it).You can play this with an xbox controller.You are able to grab "puzzle cube keys" through a platform.You should only buy this game if a huge discount or huge discount coupon. Otherwise it is not worth getting it. 3/10

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												I wanted to recommend it, but I just can't. Polarity is too short. There's only around a dozen levels in the "story" mode, 10 bonus levels, and 3 floating green things per level to collect. If you can find someone to join you, there's also some local coop and versus multiplayer but it doesn't last long either.I will give the developer credit, it is a good concept. The way the entire game plays out, it reminds me of Portal in so many ways without feeling like a rip-off. For what it is, the game is decent. But it's just so lacking in content, story, and personality.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												Everything about this game feels cheap. ugly sounds, the running sound is just segments of white noise and keeps going if you bump into a wall text tutorials explaining the mechanics, interrupting gameplay very buggy physics, cubes pass through things bad lighting in some places ugly menus uninteresting level design, it's immediately clear what you have to do collectibles are not even hidden or challenging to getMost of the time I fell down because platforms go from zero to top speed instantly, and then I had to walk a long way back up. They have a "read me" section in the main menu in which they literally apologize for this game. They could make this into a reasonable game if they replaced the physics, sounds, levels, and added an actual story. The idea could work.I paid 19 cents for it, which is about the right price. Don't buy it for anything more than that!

content:
Posted: January 10
												This game is not worth $10. The bundle this game comes with is worth the same or less as the other games in the same bundle ($2). Why? Too short and too easy. I see this game as a missed opportunity or feels unfinished. Any previous criticisms this game got are justified. Luckily, I got this game on sale.Also the developers seem to have no real focus on the game. Local coop? Are you kidding me? On Steam? Should have focused on single player only. Coop would work for a game like the Portal series, not a game like this. Oh yeah, this game shouldn't be compared to the Portal series. DDOS mode is worthless too.Granted, I think this game has some redeeming factors. Rarely do I play a game designed in Unity that plays smooth. The assets must be simple or something. If the developers behind TRI: Of Friendship and Madness used their wall-walking mechanics in Polarity and puzzles were created like Polarity but better, I think we might have something special here. Those games being standalone however, bleh. Pass on both of them.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												-Third try reviewing Polarity-Indie, as it´s ment to!No, seriously.They promised this one to be one of the most fun puzzles since Portal. As the lastly mentioned one is one of my favourite games ever, I decided to buy this. (And because it was cheap.) In my eyes, the developers didn´t lie with that.To keep my review as short as possible despite including all information I will make a list for you.Pros:+Fun to play+Actually well made levels+Decent difficulty+New and interesting game mechanic (Polarity)+Achievements that aren´t out of place+Collectable obstacles all over the levels+Suitable sound design+Calm and motivating soundtrack+Full Coop-campaign+Didn´t discover any bugs so far+Takes some time until completation+In sale like every second week +Often available for 90% off or less in a bundleCons:-Absolutely horrible visuals-Graphically bugged surroundings-Missing textures at some parts-Irrelevant story which doesn´t make the game any better-Coop requires friend, be lucky finding someoneOne last thing I have to admit is, that the developers put a "readme"- file into the options menu saying you "thanks" for playing their game. I am not sure about whether I should call this is awkwad or somewhat cute, but I would feel sorry for not telling the developers:"Here you are. A positive review for your game."And to all others I´d be sorry not to say:"As you can see, I can recommend Polarity. If you are into puzzles you shouldn´t miss this. If you don´t need a game with beautiful graphics and awesome detail but with fun to play instead, here you go. If you have a friend to play the coop-mode with, this might also be worth a try. If you don´t identify with any of those persons then you can still buy this during annother mass discount."Final score:4/58/1084/100

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												The story and gameplay is lackluster, bringing almost nothing new to the table to keep it fresh. Each level feels similar to the last, and has a hollow sense of accomplishment. It's easy to forget the story even exists by the time you reach the one-note, pointless ending screen. The gameplay itself is god-awful, with incredibly wonky physics that accomplish such things as nearly breaking your screen from a decent fall, or shifting cubes across the stage when it's impossible to do so (rotating a portion of the stage also rotates any cubes that come from it, even if it's not inside said rotated area). The UI is clunky, poorly designed (Can't go to options without quitting everything you're doing), and the game looks ugly overall.The only redeeming factors I could think of would be its short length, which made it semi-bearable to finish, and its low price tag.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												"One of the most fun puzzle/platformers since Portal"... That is, if you ignore 80% of them. This game is bad, like really bad. The whole description feel way too pretentious, if you didn't noticed.The story is basically a sad attempt to put a goal for the characters. It's almost non-existent, and I pretty much forgot about it right after the third level.Level-design is really bad, bland, and don't expect challenges, unless for like 2-3 levels.Almost no indication on how certain mechanics works, which is a real pain. I spent the whole single player campaign on resetting levels when I couldn't get a cube before learning that you can click on the arrow to make it respawn.The only thing making the game really difficult, it's the number of bugs in it. Also, the physics. Jumping on a moving platform makes you go faster than the platform. Even when you don't want to move. There's a whole level about moving and jumping and a moving platform, and it's easily the worse level of it. Are a little selections of bugs: Getting stuck under platforms, between platforms, no button response, and the worse of it: while playing as Player 1, you can make player 2 drop their cubes with a mouse button. Like.. Why?Those co-op levels are a real pain to play with someone, it's way easier to do it by yourself with a keyboard and mouse + a controller.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Not exactly your definition of a puzzle game.Me, and a couple of my peers got this game 90% off. I ended up paying something like $.50 for it or whatever, and for that price, it is somewhat worth it. So, what's the game like? Well... simple. Way too simple. The game really just consists of you, the player, running around collecting these "data fragments" and getting to the end goal. Maybe you jump up a lift, or activate a switch, but overall the package feels in complete. There are some "puzzle" elements in the game though. For one, you have a strange color changing ability (how original). You press a button, and you change from red to blue, or vice versa. Neat ain't it? Well again, this is mostly used to cross walls or bridges, it mostly is half-asses stuff that you're gonna forget. Also there are these colour cubes. Red and blue also, you chuck em across the map and they activate things... how fun and original. So how do you progress? Well as said before you collect these data fragments, which are placed around the map creatively... not really. In the easier levels you can find them right in front of you, and instead of solving puzzles to get to them, it's pretty much a scavenger hunt. Luckily they're almost always poorly hidden and easy to get to. There is a healthy amount of levels but you'll probably get through them in less than 2 hours. Co-op levels are very dumb, as they don't really give you an incentive to actually work together, and also it's local only, so in reality you can just complete everything yourself and just pick up the other controller and finish it. There is also a mode where you literally just chuck cubes in your opponents goal for 30 seconds or so, also local only.How about some positives? Well there is some at least. The game is very easy to run. Your grand-mums computer could probably run it well. The music is quite nice, and that's it. WOW. This game is very mediocre at best and it tries to be portal but it just ends up as some generic indie game that the developers spent 1 day making and tried to make some quick money off it. Don't buy it for $10 or $.50 because it's really just a waste of time. And a even bigger slap in the face is that the fact that they updated it two years after it released, and you expect a huge content update or something and all they do is add a couple of songs. Wow just f*cking great guys.Don't buy this, go buy a CS skin or find something else to waste your money on.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												Before anything else I would like to state that Polarity is nothing like Portal.  If you want a puzzle-centric game that stands out for the genre similar to Portal then you should check out Mind: Path to Thalamus,  Anti-Chamber, The Witness, or the Talos Principle - all excellent in their own right and infinitely more engaging, stimulating and challenging.  Pros-Smooth gameplay-Graphics are decent and nice to look atCons-Very short (~1-2 hours)-Puzzles don't even feel like puzzles. They're more like common sense obstacle courses that require no thought.-Cubes in the game glitch out and disappear often.-No story whatsoever unless you count two lines of text before and after you finish, literally.I picked this up for like 1$ and it was painfully below average and unoriginal.  I played this simply to kill some time and was on my phone while playing because it didn't require much thinking.  I recommend avoiding it entirely and finding a puzzler that lives up to the genre.
