Posted: April 2, 2016
PLEASE NOTE BEFORE WE BEGIN!I ONLY suggest you purchase this game if it's on sale for $5.00 or less. While I did enjoy the game, it is by no means worth their $10.00 asking price. I rate the games I play depending on if I feel it was worth what I spent. I got this game for approximately $1.50 and feel it was worth the money. Puzzles!This game isn't a brain teaser. You won't spend hours and hours on difficult puzzles. The game flies by extremely fast because almost all of the puzzles are very straightforward and quick to solve. Which is good and bad, depending on the player. If you're like me, you want to be challenged and feel clever at the end of a puzzle game. You want to feel like you really accomplished something. This game doesn't give you that at all. This is more of a relax and play some easy puzzles with the SO when there's nothing on TV. In being relaxed and straightforward it does a very good job. The gameplay doesn't feel rushed and doesn't require a lot of concentration like Portal does. There are only two or three puzzles that actually require you to move quickly or decisively, the rest of the time you can just mosey your way through. Story!What story? I'm sorry, but that was pretty well pointless. I ended up making up my own story as I went along to make it a bit more interesting than a few lines of text at the beginning and end of the game. The Goal! I also couldn't figure out if the end goal was to finish the puzzle or collect all of the data nodes. It seemed like I could complete the puzzle just fine and then it wasn't until much later that I got a splash telling me I needed to collect X more nodes before I could go to the next level. For me, they were just the nodes on that level, so I'm not sure if it changes depending on how many I have or not. I guess collecting nodes is the end goal since it sounds like I can't progress without enough, but the game itself isn't very clear on that at the start since I finished a puzzle or two accidentally without all the nodes. Gameplay!Let's start at the very beginning. The Tutorial was a little on the light side. I don't know if I missed a bit of it or not, but you can click on the spawning spots for the cubes and it will spit out another one if you accidentally throw your current one out of reach. Like I say, I don't know if I just missed the text or if it wasn't there, but it was a key aspect of the game I missed out on for a good seven or eight levels before I accidentally stumbled across it, restarting the level each time I lost my cube. Besides that I suppose it served it's purpose. Told you how to move, pick up/throw, and the primary objectives. There were no ways to check/change/reset keybindings from inside of the game and NO WAY TO CHANGE THE MOUSE SENSITIVITY! Holy cow it was WAY too high for my taste and I couldn't seem to find a way to turn it down until I went into Razer Synapse and lowered my mouse's sensitivity manually. The keybindings for the controller were extremely awkward as well, and like I said, no way to change them from inside of the game itself. (It doesn't help that I usually don't use a controller.)The sockets where you put the cubes are buggy as all getout. Some of them will snag the cube from half the room away, some will only grab it if you literally hit it directly, and others will grab it and then drop it or pull it toward them and then let it go to fall into the black abyss and make you walk all the way back to the spawn for the cube. They're extremely inconsistent. For instance, on one level, you have to throw the cube across the room and hit a moving socket. I must have wasted a dozen cubes trying to get it. I would get it, and then it would just bounce off of the socket and leave me raging. I managed to hit it directly two times before it finally grabbed it.The way the cubes interact with the jump plates is also buggy. Frequently (35-40% of the time) the cube will literally just plop down on the jump plate and sit there. Then most of the time you aren't even able to get the cube back from the plate, particularly if it's a turnable jump plate, you'll just sit there spam right-clicking trying to pick up your god forsaken cube while the pad does a rendition of Dead or Alive's only good song.*The walls are made of tar. When you strafe into them or walk perpendicular to them when using a controller (Because I guess you're always strafing with a controller?) they will stop/slow you, like getting stuck on fly paper. They do the same thing to the cube, freezing it in place and yanking it out of your hands, frequently over a pit, next to a pit, or in a pit. ♥♥♥♥ing pits This might seem minor, until you find it happening constantly. It does ware on your nerves. I assume this contributes a bit to the lack of physics when it comes to the cube bouncing/rolling. When you throw it against a wall it's as if you threw it full force into a stack of pillows. The cubes also have a tendency to disappear randomly after hitting something hard (usually after falling a long distance.) In the end, to play this, you need to be relaxed. You can't be taking it seriously (as I was at first), because the little bugs will drive you absolutely batshit. Now for the good aspects of the gameplay!Throwing is awesome and it adds a good mechanic to the game, making it less of a Portal clone.  The puzzles were diverse enough to keep me interested. They weren't all carbon copies of the last, and the introduction to new mechanics every couple of levels made for a nice little changeup once in a while (Such as the Crazy Cube Color Changer patent pending or the rotating jump plates.) The variety (Red and Blue) of cubes added a small extra level of complexity, rather than a one cube fits all approach. If the creators were to do any more work, I would love to see green and yellow cubes implemented as well. The Sounds!The footsteps and music are extremely repetative. I muted all sounds after half hour and turned on some Devildriver. If there were more variety in the music and footsteps it wouldn't have bugged me as much. Co-Op!Before I get into the Co-Op. I did the co-op, all of it, by myself. I plugged in a controller and it took me about forty-five minutes. I did it mostly for the challenge and to see if Co-Op were as Co-Op as advertised. To be fair, there are four missions (If I recall correctly) that were genuinely difficult alone and designed to be done with two people playing. Most of the others were pretty well a solo run with a tagalong that would throw a block up to a high place once in a while. None of them really required any interactive coordination between the two players. Really the only time I would have needed someone were the levels where you have to avoid blocks/lasers at the same time. There were no OH MY GOD I'M GOING TO DIE IF YOU DON'T HURRY moments. OVERALL! It's a solid start for something that could be pretty cool if the dev(s) decide(s) to keep going and expand. But like I said at the top, I would only recommend it for five bucks or less, ten is a bit too much for an hour or two of entertainment. It's no portal. But it's better than most early-access ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that's on steam right now.* The song in question

Posted: November 15, 2015
												To be honest, I feel kind of cheated since the trailer you can see in the store page shows some stuff that doesn't seem to be in the game, the game itself is interesting, has a nice gameplay and stands somewhat unique, I wouldn't say is like Portal... at all.I haven't played the co-op levels, but I was able to beat all the single player levels is less than 2 hours, so the game is really short and the full price seems way too much, however, the game goes on sale often, high sale prices as well.There is no story, well, they say you're a hacker and so on (but doing parkour has nothing to do with being a hacker though) and you only get pieces of story at the start and end of the single player stuff, considering this game compared itself with Portal I was expecting some nice story, not another GlaDOS nor anything like that, but at least some story...The gameplay just consists on using cubes to active stuff and progress on the level, the description says "gameplay found in games like Portal, but is made exclusively for experienced gamers", yet the difficulty seems way to low, I wouldn't call myself an experienced gamer at all, the game is just way too easy, a couple of trial and error here and there, but it doesn't turn really difficult."You’ll need clever wits and fast reflexes" is also a lie, as I said, some things that appear in the trailer do not seem to appear in the game (like the dropping part with the lasers), as I said, the game is really easy.I also found some bugs while playing, pretty much you not being able to step higher and getting stuck in a place, the cubes getting stuck while you "recall" them and they can also go through platforms they shouldn't be able to (cubes can no-clip).I'll give the game a thumbs up since it's still interesting and it goes on sale often, but it's way too simple for it's full price.

												Most of the negative reviews suffer from "I don't like it because it's not Portal" syndrome. But I think this is a really interesting game. While it does have some similarities to Portal, it is just an indie game and it isn't right to compare the two. I thought that this game was incredibly smart with its level design. Sure, a lot of the levels are not that difficult, but there are a few that really make you scratch your head (especially bonus level 7 and co-op level 9). I bought the game when it was on sale for $0.19, but I would honestly pay the $4.99 for the game.PROS-Co-op campaign has by far the best and trickiest levels; really fun to play with a friend-The regular campaign and bonus levels are fun. Most are easy to finish, but difficult to completely master (get all data pieces)CONS-Some levels are very easy, making the game kind of short-The DDOS Attack Versus mode was not as exciting as I expected-No online multiplayer (co-op or versus)Also just a helpful hint for controller input mapping - "horizontal controller" refers to the left analog stick (the one moving your guy) and "vertical controller" refers to the right analog stick (the one moving the camera).

Posted: July 30, 2015
												Let me start off by saying if I could give a "neutral" recommendation, I would.  Polarity's concept is really cool, if not 100% original, and it handles really well.I understand it's supposed to be in a sort of hacker-esque online setting, but there's a difference between computer-like visuals and "plain".  It would have been really nice to see some designs that look like the backs of computer chips.Now, about graphics.  I don't know how, but Polarity makes my Geforce GTX 770 graphics card have a hard time, but it can render Tera: Fate of Arun on max graphics settings for hours on end before it starts to overheat.  Honestly, I would have to applaud the game for that if nothing else.There wasn't a lot to dislike about Polarity, honestly.  The puzzles weren't too simple or too difficult, the controls weren't bad (except on a controller oh god why), and the  difficulty level wasn't stagnant between levels.  But even though there weren't a lot of negatives, there also weren't a lot of positives.  There wasn't a lot of story, there weren't a lot of unique gameplay mechanics (which isn't listed as a negative because it's really hard to do that nowadays), and the...You know what?  I'm tired.  Not gonna finish the review.It wasn't bad.  It wasn't good.  I wouldn't recommend it.

Posted: August 22, 2015
												4/10I really wanted to enjoy this game, but I'm just unable to get past its flaws. It's a fun little puzzle game, with nice level design, but suffers from numerous issues that would lead me to avoid recommending it.First off, this it's a really bad console port. The options are practically useless. I'm unable to change my controls, or adjust the visuals besides monitor resolution. The keyboard/mouse support isn't well implemented either. To make this worse, around one third of the game is the multiplayer campaign, which isn't even playable. The game only supports local split-screen. It has absolutely no network support, not even over LAN. This effectively takes out a massive chunk of the game.To top it all off, the game feels very clunky, and isn't terribly interesting either. You end up spending most of your time playing just trying to move around the stages, as opposed to actually solving the puzzles. This game could've been great, but because of the oversight of the developpers, it really doesn't feel like a complete game.

Posted: September 13, 2015
												A fun, quick puzzle game. You can easily beat the single player blind in under 80 minutes. However, the title is a bit misleading. Imagine if Portal was called Speed Gel. It's kind of like that. The whole polarity aspect is kind of a side note. It's barely used in the story mode, and only becomes part of the puzzles in the bonus levels. In story mode, all it's used for is making selectively usable floors and doors. The primary puzzle elements isn't polarity, but more the management of cubes. Swapping, changing, throwing, resetting, and putting them in receptacles that activate things. Sound familiar? Yup, this game is basically Portal without the portals, and gel replaced by a polarity function.Shame there aren't any achievements for bringing a cube to the end with you. You can do that in most levels.Also, bonus points for bonus level 6. Not only can you skip the entire puzzle with a sequence breaking jump; but if you miss that jump, you might fall out of the world by missing the deathzone in the pit.

Posted: September 8, 2016
Product received for free
 TL;DR It's a pretty solid game with the few exceptions of bugs and painfully simple puzzles The game is pretty much a straight rip of Portal, but still enjoyable at times the game has many "borrowed" (Borrowed being the more generous term) mechanics for Portal ie. companion cube-esque puzzles, avoiding laser on a moving platform, etc. However, the game still makes for a fun and light puzzle game to pass an afternoon, but don't expect it to take up too much time. At this point, I have beaten this game (including bonus levels) with just over two hours, and I don't know if I really want to invite some on over to play the co-op missions(no online co-op). The game is sprinkled with a few bugs that were not really unexpected from a small indie dev, but can be annoying none the less (ie. clipping issues with cubes or cubes just straight up disappearing).Overall, if you're looking to  play  a first person puzzle game that comes with some real challenge and story, just pick up the portal bundle. However if you're just looking for a way to throw away a few hours on something sort of challenging and fun, and this game happens to be on sale, why not but I wouldn't recommend paying the full price, I mean I got it for free.

Posted: September 7, 2016
												General Pros:To be fair, it's not a bad game. The gameplay is solid, the physics are mostly solid (excluding bugs), the graphics are a bit lacklustre, but are generally clean and consistent, it has trading cards, it's a good time and the game goes on sale enough to be worth its sale price. I would only buy this game when the sales go for 3$CAD (2.50$USD) or under.General Cons:Why so many negative reviews? Sketchy devs, graphics problems, frame rate issues, general bugs, uninteresting story, very easy, no replay value, general mediocrity and no online co-op. For more information, read some negative reviews.Why the up rating:I actually enjoyed the game for the price I got it at. The single player is generally quite easy, but there was enough challenge to keep me interested for casual play. The co-op is a good time if you have the controllers to do it. It's well designed and harder than the single-player levels. If you're looking for your typical impossible puzzle game that feeds the weak to the gods of "online guides" with tons of levels ranking up to an impossible difficulty, go somewhere else. It's a rather short game that's fairly easy to complete. It's too short to get repetitive, but long enough to get engaged in. I personally like this style, but it's not for everyone and thus, I'm recommending it, but not for everyone :D

Posted: September 9, 2016
Product received for free
												With a puzzle structure similar to that of the "Portal" nature, it is easy to see this game as a rip off. Although, it is very much it's own game. having being built by a very small team as a hobby, it is obvious that this is not going to be a AAA title. But it's not neccissarily bad. A few object placement errors here and there, and fairly basic gameplay does not make a bad game. Also, both of these can be fixed with a bit of time and an update.The first half hour playing this game, the only frustration I had was a small one at that; The constant tutorial popups. They just got slightly annoying, but tollerable. Other than that, I found the game to be playable and enjoyable. Like I mentioned, the game has a portal-like puzzle structure with similar mechanics, but they are not completely the same. Overall, considering the small dev team and the time put into the game, I would say the game is really not bad. It's a fun, entertaining little something to do that passes time, which, for a small indie puzzle game, is all I expect it to be and do.I have recieved this game for free as a gift from te developers and I am appreciative of the free game. Thanks guys!

Posted: October 22, 2015
												The Good-Enjoyable portal clone-Gameplay is quite fun-Music is solid-Relatively unique visual style (reminds me of Tron)-Teaches the player controlls without holding their hand in learning gameplay mechanicsThe Meh Stuff-Sounds were hit and miss - example: jump sounds were bad and off time with visuals fairly often but sounds for the cube and polarity shift were good-Gameplay elements were unique but there are only a few to learnThe Bad-EXTREMELY short game - I finished the single player and bonus missions in one sitting; less than an hour and a half total-The jump mechanics do not function very well, especially when trying to make multiple jumps in a row. This makes some levels a bit frustrating.-EXTREMELY easy game - even the most "challenging" levels only take a couple minutes to finish. Several of the data (the things you collect each level) are in plain sight or hidden in painfully obvious hiding places. There is little to no challange in the puzzles. Overall, I thought the game was enjoyable but definately not worth $11. I did not play the coop or vs modes, so perhaps these modes give some extra worth. I bought it on sale so it was dirt cheap. TL;DRBUY IT IF IT IS ON SALE, DON'T BUY IT IF IT IS NOT ON SALE

Posted: November 15, 2015
												To be honest, I feel kind of cheated since the trailer you can see in the store page shows some stuff that doesn't seem to be in the game, the game itself is interesting, has a nice gameplay and stands somewhat unique, I wouldn't say is like Portal... at all.I haven't played the co-op levels, but I was able to beat all the single player levels is less than 2 hours, so the game is really short and the full price seems way too much, however, the game goes on sale often, high sale prices as well.There is no story, well, they say you're a hacker and so on (but doing parkour has nothing to do with being a hacker though) and you only get pieces of story at the start and end of the single player stuff, considering this game compared itself with Portal I was expecting some nice story, not another GlaDOS nor anything like that, but at least some story...The gameplay just consists on using cubes to active stuff and progress on the level, the description says "gameplay found in games like Portal, but is made exclusively for experienced gamers", yet the difficulty seems way to low, I wouldn't call myself an experienced gamer at all, the game is just way too easy, a couple of trial and error here and there, but it doesn't turn really difficult."You’ll need clever wits and fast reflexes" is also a lie, as I said, some things that appear in the trailer do not seem to appear in the game (like the dropping part with the lasers), as I said, the game is really easy.I also found some bugs while playing, pretty much you not being able to step higher and getting stuck in a place, the cubes getting stuck while you "recall" them and they can also go through platforms they shouldn't be able to (cubes can no-clip).I'll give the game a thumbs up since it's still interesting and it goes on sale often, but it's way too simple for it's full price.

												I liked solving each puzzle in each map, each level was different from the others which gave it that challenge. The levels last a couple of minutes at first but do get harder as you progress to end up taking around 10 minutes or more. The levels concist of using these blocks that could be called energy orbs to function platforms and make things work/move to get around the map. You need to collect these data objects which each level has 3 inside them, each data object is either hidden or there is a puzzle challenge to get to them such as changing the colour of a enery source because a slot is a different colour needed to make an lift function which can take you to that data object. When you've collected the data objects then you can make your way to the end of the level ready for the next one. I had a lot of fun solving the puzzles as they weren't too hard. I would recommend this game to anyone.

Posted: November 10, 2015
												Disclaimer: My first 'proper' review of a game.TL;DR:  Concept and potential is there, execution is lacking. Overpriced. Not actually a puzzle game.Pros:ConceptGame MechanicsSprinting (Timesaver!)VisualsCons:PriceBad execution.'Puzzle' game.Buggy. (Clip through platforms, cubes getting stuck, cubes randomly resetting.)After completing the singleplayer with all collectibles, and as much as I would love to recommend this game, I just can't. Don't get me wrong, the concept for this game is amazing and the potential is there if they want to expand on it.PriceIt's just that for €11 you aren't getting what you paid for. The length of the game, even when getting all collectibles and completing all the bonus levels (apart from co-op) is just over an hour. I would definitely recommend this if you could get it for <€3, but any more is just not worth the €/hour value.ConceptNow for the concept, the idea and potential in the game mechanics is great, but the execution is lacking. Quite a lot.The game reminded me a lot of Q.U.B.E. mixed with Portal. The visuals are kinda similar to these two games, and the game mechanics for the 'puzzles' have some similarities to these two games. But they just fall short in the puzzle department. 'Puzzle' tagAfter playing through the game it's more like a platformer/cubethrow than a real puzzle game. The only real puzzle element in this was finding the place to place/throw cubes at. After you found those it was all just platforming to the end of the level and onto the next one. Occasionally you would miss a collectible that you'd have to look for, but most of those you would come across regularly, or find when you would miss a jump. There wasn't a single moment in the game where I had to think about what to do in the level beforehand, it was all just look for the cube and the platform to put it on to advance.VerdictMy final verdict for this game would be a 4/10. I encountered too many random bugs for it to score any higher, from me clipping through platforms to my cube just randomly resetting when I was trying to use the launch pads.

Posted: June 27, 2015
												Polarity is a frequent target of outlandishly-good Steam sales. In theory, it goes for five dollars - already a low-risk investment - but in practice, you can generally pay more for a stale gumball than a copy of Polarity. I thought about typing this entire review without one reference to Portal, but the comparison is unavoidable. As a first-person puzzle-platformer that achieves diversity in level design without throwing too many game mechanics into the mix, Polarity succeeds in many of the same ways that Portal did, albeit on a much smaller scope. But to consider Polarity a decent poor-man's Portal is to do it a disservice. By utilizing a mechanic that is less visually jarring, Polarity makes similar gameplay more accessible for casual gamers, and while it is an easy play-through for most gamers, it provides solid and balanced entertainment throughout.I don't think the premise can be laid out any more clearly than in the first sentence of the game: "You are a hacker." Lucky you. Supposedly, you travel a mainframe seeking out protected data for the agency that hired you, but a more-salient way to look at the objective is "Pick up the green glowy things and get to the end of the level." Each level has three bits of data, and while you can move on without collecting all three, the game does acknowledge 100% completion. Generally speaking, the data aren't too hidden, but it is worth it to explore the big, open rooms that comprise most of the game world to see what you can find.In Portal, you used the titular portals to play with basic physics to complete levels. In Polarity, the concept is much simpler: you switch yourself between two color "poles," red and blue. The levels contain structures made of red and blue light. When your polarity matches, you phase right through the object; when your polarity does not match, it is as solid to you as the room itself. Alternatively, if the object is a laser and your polarity does not match, you die. Challenges sometimes require changing polarities while in motion, and even while in free-fall, so that you pass through one object but not another.The levels also include red and blue Not-Companion Cubes. (I am a masterful and original comedian. Nobody has ever made that observation before.) These cubes are subject to the same rules of polarity that you are, and they can also power platforms and other machines when placed in circles with outlines of matching color. You are not able to directly change the polarity of a given cube, but there are green windows through which you can launch the cubes to change them. Occasionally, you will come to obstacles which you can pass through, but which your cube cannot.The gameplay is incredibly smooth, and the sense of size and scope is nice. For levels that are largely wide-open rooms without too many moving bits, I was worried that after a time they would feel bland and empty, but instead I often had a sense of awe, looking to platforms three stories up that I knew I could find a way to. I did, however, want more from the cubes. In most cases, the cube was simply a proxy for a button or switch, and I felt like more could have been done with switching the polarity of individual cubes, or getting a single cube to help you in multiple ways.Ultimately, the game is a success, providing a short journey through a world that needs little explanation, gives adequate time to learn the mechanics, and increases the challenge as you go. By the end, it is perhaps a bit too short and a bit too easy, but even if you breeze through all of its main and bonus levels, it provides entertainment along the way. Well worth the five-dollar price point - and if you find it at a discount, do not hesitate.

Posted: January 15, 2016
												The physics are horrible, your character falls way to fast, and objects almost don't at all when thrown. And it has the physics effect where when you jump off of a moving object, you keep moving with it, which is a problem when you're trying to jump onto thin floating pathways. The game is very short, and the puzzles can hardly be called puzzles. The hardest thing about the puzzles is finding all of the cubes to continue, and then I get to the end of what the call the single player campaign and tell me I need to find 11 more Fragments to continue. I didn't realize I needed fragments for anything but the trophies, so it's trying to get me to play through the entire campaign again to collect all of the fragments (which aren't challenging to get) to continue through the campaign it says I beat? There is also no voice acting, so there is no reason to want to keep going. If you want a fun puzzle game with better graphics, better physics, and is cheaper, go for the old Portal flash game. Its more rewarding, difficult and polished.Polarity is like if Portal didn't have portals or good physics. Just cubes.I want to give it a bad rating, but its much better than what squeezes out of Greenlight now, so I'll give it a 4.5/10.

Posted: January 16, 2016
												I lost interest in under an hour. The puzzles are far too easy, and the difficuly curve is stagnant if it even exists. I may come back and beat it,  and I'm still glad I bought it, but If i had paid the full $10.99 for this I would be extremely dissapointed. I would recommend buying this game if it were under $2, and if you prefer relaxed puzzle games.Why is there a run button? I feel like no one wants to walk, but it was just added because a lot of games have one. The areas that make you run/jump and change colors require 4 key presses, shift being the most awkward, as though I'm playing twister with my hand. just make the player always run. Sometimes I'll throw a box at the wall to grab a data fragments, and the box goes through the wall. Two things here: data should be collected on contact, secondly, fix the wall glitch.I'm not a fan of the use and design of the UI. The tutorial buttons pause the game, almost always when I was in mid jump, for the first message, I had just happened to be clicking right as it popped up, and accidentally closed it after it showed for a 10th of a second. I never got a chance to read it. they should really just stay up, without pausing the game, and dissapear after a few seconds. lastly, I don't like that a "next level" button appears at the end, would be nicer if it just went to the next level.The game has a confusing optional yet kinda required data collection, side thing. I say take that out entirely, and force the player to do every puzzle. This would remove the need for back-tracking, level selection, and all of those things that break the immersion of the game. Most of the data finding added nothing to the game, other than make me bored whilst checking nooks and crannies. Only a few data hiding spot added some fun, and you might as well just work those into the mandatory path of the level.Story was non-existent, normally I don't care, but, it's just another example of how the game aimed low in all areas except... technical implementation: the game is almost bug free; It handles pretty well. The only bug I saw was mentioned earlier, Nothing else really annoyed me, outside of the game's design.Keep at it, and try to take more risks. It's a neat concept that can lead to a really great game, but it just needs better level design

Posted: January 17, 2016
												I'm recommending it on sale. It's a good game, like a Portal spinoff, but the controls are a little clunky. More reminiscent of QUBE than Portal, really. The running and swapping colors is very fluid, but the sections with the slow moving platforms had me rocketing to my death like I'd jumped off a speeding car. Other than that, nice and relaxing puzzles.

Posted: May 23, 2015
												For me Polarity felt rather mediocre. The main innovation, the polarity of things and your character is a nice idea, which in my opinion could've been taken much further though. The game also feels rather unpolished at some edges. And the entire game with all achievements can be finished in 4 hours, which feels rather anticlimactic. In the end I think the game is okay but you might even want to wait for a sale on this one, considering there are other games which give you a lot more for the same price.

												I will say that this game is fairly easy and there isn't much to it, but that doesn't make it bad. Sure, it's short, it isn't nearly as challenging as an other puzzle game I've played (Portal, The Talos Priciple, Portal 2, etc.), and it likes to stutter from time to time, but it is only $0.54....oh wait...that's the price at 95% off >,> And if you are wondering, it IS possible to play most of the co-op levels by yourself, I am working on the rest of them when I find the time, for those of you without any friends....that play this game of course...because I have friends....they...just don't play this game.But like I said before, it isn't a bad game, but it really isn't worth the $20.00 it would cost you if it wasn't on sale.I'd rate it higher if the price was either lower than twenty dollars or if it had more content, but for now, I'd give it a 4/10.

Posted: January 12, 2016
												For just .54 cents this game is a steal!  Fun, first person puzzle game.  Reverse your polarity to go thru like-colored force fields.  Collect data, collect colored cubes to activate doors, ramps, etc.  So far, this game is fun, the puzzles are not too difficult yet, but I can see that they are getting progressively harder.   It reminds me of Anti-Chamber, yet does not appear as difficult to achieve.  It is a great casual game, when the high-end games are stressing you out. :)   Get it while it's on sale!

Posted: May 12, 2015
												Decentish puzzles at times, but the data fragments feel more like a scavenger hunt slapped on top of the puzzling.I see no reason to have a sprint button, when you are pretty much always going to sprint anyway (give my shift key some rest man)The puzzles so far as I've seen them are rather obvious (unsure of later levels, but the difficulty did increase a tad), and will often involve dexterity/aiming challenges. It is also possible to get yourself stuck in some of the levels.Good enough game for its pricepoint, but don't expect wonders of puzzle design.

Posted: May 12, 2015
												It's a pretty short game (finished the main story and first three bonus levels in a little over three hours), but it's a lot of fun.  The graphics are easy on the eyes, simple, clean, and aesthetically appealing.  It's not a difficult game, which I found refreshing after stuggling through the last painful level of A Story About My Uncle.   Each level is short, takes about ten minutes or under for each one, which is nice if you're not looking for a super lengthy gaming session.  The only complaints I have are that turning around seems to take forever (you just pan and pan and pan), and sometimes the physics for the blocks are a little weird.  I had a block get stuck in the floor more than once, but the recall block function makes up for this shortcoming.All in all, a quick, enjoyable game.  Made me happy.

Posted: May 13, 2015
												Fantastic little puzzler. Nothing too taxing on the brain, but attempting to find all of the data packs (there are three of them hidden in each level) can be a real challenge and the idea of polarity-switching is used to good effect. The similarities to Portal are well-known at this point; you find yourself in a sleek, enclosed environment and use your wits (and cubes) to reach the exit. If you enjoyed Portal, you'll enjoy this, but it would be doing the game a disservice to call it a Portal clone; it has its own ideas and systems that are well thought-out and smoothly executed throughout. The game is void of any real plot or humour, but those things aren't needed here. It's a simple little game and quite a relaxing way to flex your puzzling muscles for an hour or two, without any extra baggage forcefully added on. I've not been able to enjoy the co-op campaign just yet, but if the singleplayer is anything to go by then it must be a lot of fun. There's certainly potential for a sequel here and I hope to see more from this developer in the future.

Posted: May 13, 2015
												Pretty unpolished game. Texture errors/level layout bugs resulting in  needing to jump over inch high bumps in the ground that honestly should have been caught if the creators played through their game once. Some mechanics of the game don't work particularly well. For example, the boost mechanic doesn't have great programing resulting in not hitting a boost or hitting it and going too far. Also short, I collected all the data in under 2 hours, which isn't even necessary for solving all the puzzles. I'm glad I got it on sale because I don't think 2 hours of game play with no replay value is worth $5

												This game could be great, but instead it's mediocre at best. The titular gimmick (being able to switch between "Red Polarity" and "Blue Polarity") is very rarely used for anything besides bypassing certain gates, the game is very boring since you don't have very many characters to talk to you throughout the game, you don't have much of a goal, and jumping is a crapshoot if you're playing on a computer. I bought the game when it was on sale for $0.10, and I can certainly say that I got my money's worth back, and I feel bad for anyone who paid the full $11. Maybe if this game was $1, or even $5, it would be worth it, but there are so many problems all I can say about this game is that it's so bland it's mediocre, and if you want to spend $11 of your money you should spend it on the original Portal, if you want a game like it, or if you're looking for new Indie games to play I'd recommend buying Q.U.B.E.: Director's Cut or the Binding of Isaac: Afterbirth.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												Polarity is an overall very nice, Portal-like experience.PROS:- The puzzles are relatively simple, but engaging.- The gameplay is good and makes you want to keep progressing through the levels.- The minimalistic style is pleasant to look at.- The music is very relaxing and a joy to listen to.CONS:- I found the sound effects to be so annoying that after the first level, I went into the options to see if I can lower their volume - for some reason you can only turn them on and off, and I was forced to do the latter. The game doesn't really lose much if you do, and you are able to fully immerse yourself in the music that way.- Some of the level design choices aren't particularly fortunate, like how you can't always be sure where the platform you're standing on ends, or how deadly pits and normal ground are so hard to tell apart. Also, the chambers tend to be too dark and big sometimes.- 2 or 3 levels require quickly changing the polarity mid-jump, which is a pain to accomplish sometimes.- The singleplayer campaign is pretty short, and together with the bonus levels, it can be completed in about 3 hours. (I didn't try the coop one yet, so there's that...)- The ending could offer something more satisfying than just a few lines of text...CONCLUSION:Definitely get it if it's on sale. Especially the one that lowers its price to laughable 20 cents.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												Calling Polarity "The best puzzle/platformer since Portal" is a bit of a stretch, but nonetheless, it is a decent game. It suffers from lack of polish in a few areas, and has somewhat glitchy physics at times, but for the price it's a fun little puzzle game. I came into it expecting the puzzles to get more difficult as the game went on, and to some extent they did, but each level still only takes around 2-3 minutes at most. Overall, a decent time killer if you need to waste an hour (or more if you have a co-op buddy). Good if you're looking for a laid-back puzzler, especially good for the sale price.  4/5.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												How do I review this game?I could complain about the various non game-breaking glitches. But it was only $0.19I could complain about the unimaginative plain level design with repeating textures like an early 90s shooter. But it was only $0.19I could could complain about the various texture glitches and mismatched geometry causing strange unnatural ridges for you to get stuck on and glitches to appear. But it was only $0.19I could complain about beating the main game levels in only a few minutes with little effort. But it was only $0.19I could complain about the cubes disappearing randomly, getting stuck on objects, or even getting stuck in the platform it spawns on. But it was only $0.19I could complain about some of the puzzle parts being non intuitive and requires a bit of guessing to figure out what they do. But it was only $0.19But seriously.. It's only $0.19For $0.19 you can't really complain.Actually, even for a $1 it's pretty decent.Probably not for $5. I think this is game would do well at $1The base game is rather simple but enjoyable, I think younger children may enjoy the puzzles if they can get over some of the visuals or lack thereof.The game features full controller support. However I played with a keyboard and mouse.The bonus levels are a bit more difficult and will take a bit more than a couple glances to figure out.I sadly did not have a person available at the time to play the second player for the co-op mode.The CO-OP is split screen! Would be great to play with a friend and a couple controllers.I was able to find all the data points without too much difficulty, I felt I spent just the right amount of time looking for them.The music is a bit retro 80's sci fi electronic soothing keyboard type style which fits well.Movement feels pretty good. Physics are great. I think the programmers even did a bit of nudging at points to get you to land where you need to be without frustration.You can tell a big studio did not make this game, but I still enjoyed solving the puzzles.If you have an afternoon to kill and like puzzle games, I would definitely pick this up.

Posted: November 10, 2015
												Disclaimer: My first 'proper' review of a game.TL;DR:  Concept and potential is there, execution is lacking. Overpriced. Not actually a puzzle game.Pros:ConceptGame MechanicsSprinting (Timesaver!)VisualsCons:PriceBad execution.'Puzzle' game.Buggy. (Clip through platforms, cubes getting stuck, cubes randomly resetting.)After completing the singleplayer with all collectibles, and as much as I would love to recommend this game, I just can't. Don't get me wrong, the concept for this game is amazing and the potential is there if they want to expand on it.PriceIt's just that for €11 you aren't getting what you paid for. The length of the game, even when getting all collectibles and completing all the bonus levels (apart from co-op) is just over an hour. I would definitely recommend this if you could get it for <€3, but any more is just not worth the €/hour value.ConceptNow for the concept, the idea and potential in the game mechanics is great, but the execution is lacking. Quite a lot.The game reminded me a lot of Q.U.B.E. mixed with Portal. The visuals are kinda similar to these two games, and the game mechanics for the 'puzzles' have some similarities to these two games. But they just fall short in the puzzle department. 'Puzzle' tagAfter playing through the game it's more like a platformer/cubethrow than a real puzzle game. The only real puzzle element in this was finding the place to place/throw cubes at. After you found those it was all just platforming to the end of the level and onto the next one. Occasionally you would miss a collectible that you'd have to look for, but most of those you would come across regularly, or find when you would miss a jump. There wasn't a single moment in the game where I had to think about what to do in the level beforehand, it was all just look for the cube and the platform to put it on to advance.VerdictMy final verdict for this game would be a 4/10. I encountered too many random bugs for it to score any higher, from me clipping through platforms to my cube just randomly resetting when I was trying to use the launch pads.

												Polarity is a First-Person, Indie, Local Co-Op, Puzzle, Action Startegy game that is similar to the Portal franchise, so you already know that this game is going to be good.Polarity is a game where you need to get to the end of the level. But, the Co-Op, like in Portal 2, works well. And, it's a great edition to the game.Overall, this is a pretty good game. I would recommend the Portal franchise over this, but, this is a good game, and i still recommend it to anyone who wants it,

Posted: September 7, 2016
												General Pros:To be fair, it's not a bad game. The gameplay is solid, the physics are mostly solid (excluding bugs), the graphics are a bit lacklustre, but are generally clean and consistent, it has trading cards, it's a good time and the game goes on sale enough to be worth its sale price. I would only buy this game when the sales go for 3$CAD (2.50$USD) or under.General Cons:Why so many negative reviews? Sketchy devs, graphics problems, frame rate issues, general bugs, uninteresting story, very easy, no replay value, general mediocrity and no online co-op. For more information, read some negative reviews.Why the up rating:I actually enjoyed the game for the price I got it at. The single player is generally quite easy, but there was enough challenge to keep me interested for casual play. The co-op is a good time if you have the controllers to do it. It's well designed and harder than the single-player levels. If you're looking for your typical impossible puzzle game that feeds the weak to the gods of "online guides" with tons of levels ranking up to an impossible difficulty, go somewhere else. It's a rather short game that's fairly easy to complete. It's too short to get repetitive, but long enough to get engaged in. I personally like this style, but it's not for everyone and thus, I'm recommending it, but not for everyone :D

Posted: October 13, 2016
												A fun and relatively novel puzzle game. While the puzzles border on trivial in places the game make use of some interesting game play elements. I really like the idea of the switching polarity and I think there is a lot of potential to expand upon the mechanic. The level design is simple but appealing and the soundtrack has a nice ambient, soothing quality that I think really suits the gameplay.The only real complaints I have are the polish, difficulty, and length of the game.During gameplay, there wer scattered instances of getting caught on small edges and sequences of accelerators. I don't think it detracts from gameplay too much but with the timing component it seems like this has potential to frustrate speed runners.The difficulty is obviously subjective and I understand that it can be difficult to strike a balance here. I think the game would benefit from the addition of more challenging puzzles, either by developer addition, or support for community creation.The campaign and bonus levels felt a bit short overall. Obviously there could be replay value for people wanting to improve time overal but without a leaderboard for friends this might be rather niche.Overall, I like the game and recommend it for people who like relaxing puzzle games.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												Polarity is a fun puzzle game, wher you do indeed have to think and plan ahead. Jumping and mid-air color switching provides a little bit of action to keep you going as well. The graphics aren't high-end, but they're pleasant nonetheless. However. the "data" idea is kind of silly. In addition to completing the level, you have to hunt for "data" hidden in random places around the map. It's annoying, and kind of takes away from the game. But overall, I think its a good game.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												Polarity is an overall very nice, Portal-like experience.PROS:- The puzzles are relatively simple, but engaging.- The gameplay is good and makes you want to keep progressing through the levels.- The minimalistic style is pleasant to look at.- The music is very relaxing and a joy to listen to.CONS:- I found the sound effects to be so annoying that after the first level, I went into the options to see if I can lower their volume - for some reason you can only turn them on and off, and I was forced to do the latter. The game doesn't really lose much if you do, and you are able to fully immerse yourself in the music that way.- Some of the level design choices aren't particularly fortunate, like how you can't always be sure where the platform you're standing on ends, or how deadly pits and normal ground are so hard to tell apart. Also, the chambers tend to be too dark and big sometimes.- 2 or 3 levels require quickly changing the polarity mid-jump, which is a pain to accomplish sometimes.- The singleplayer campaign is pretty short, and together with the bonus levels, it can be completed in about 3 hours. (I didn't try the coop one yet, so there's that...)- The ending could offer something more satisfying than just a few lines of text...CONCLUSION:Definitely get it if it's on sale. Especially the one that lowers its price to laughable 20 cents.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												Calling Polarity "The best puzzle/platformer since Portal" is a bit of a stretch, but nonetheless, it is a decent game. It suffers from lack of polish in a few areas, and has somewhat glitchy physics at times, but for the price it's a fun little puzzle game. I came into it expecting the puzzles to get more difficult as the game went on, and to some extent they did, but each level still only takes around 2-3 minutes at most. Overall, a decent time killer if you need to waste an hour (or more if you have a co-op buddy). Good if you're looking for a laid-back puzzler, especially good for the sale price.  4/5.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												How do I review this game?I could complain about the various non game-breaking glitches. But it was only $0.19I could complain about the unimaginative plain level design with repeating textures like an early 90s shooter. But it was only $0.19I could could complain about the various texture glitches and mismatched geometry causing strange unnatural ridges for you to get stuck on and glitches to appear. But it was only $0.19I could complain about beating the main game levels in only a few minutes with little effort. But it was only $0.19I could complain about the cubes disappearing randomly, getting stuck on objects, or even getting stuck in the platform it spawns on. But it was only $0.19I could complain about some of the puzzle parts being non intuitive and requires a bit of guessing to figure out what they do. But it was only $0.19But seriously.. It's only $0.19For $0.19 you can't really complain.Actually, even for a $1 it's pretty decent.Probably not for $5. I think this is game would do well at $1The base game is rather simple but enjoyable, I think younger children may enjoy the puzzles if they can get over some of the visuals or lack thereof.The game features full controller support. However I played with a keyboard and mouse.The bonus levels are a bit more difficult and will take a bit more than a couple glances to figure out.I sadly did not have a person available at the time to play the second player for the co-op mode.The CO-OP is split screen! Would be great to play with a friend and a couple controllers.I was able to find all the data points without too much difficulty, I felt I spent just the right amount of time looking for them.The music is a bit retro 80's sci fi electronic soothing keyboard type style which fits well.Movement feels pretty good. Physics are great. I think the programmers even did a bit of nudging at points to get you to land where you need to be without frustration.You can tell a big studio did not make this game, but I still enjoyed solving the puzzles.If you have an afternoon to kill and like puzzle games, I would definitely pick this up.

Pros: Interesting puzzlesAppealing visualsShould run on almost any PCOccasionally clever level designNew mechanics are introduced organically, so it is very easy to learn how they work by just experimentingCons:While visuals are pleasant, they are very rudimentary and this could detract from some people's experienceAlmost no plot at allCo-op is split-screen onlyVery short playthroughI found it too easy to blow through each level, and most data nodes (3 collectables in each level) aren't really hidden at allThe cons I have listed, while obviously negative points, don't really detract from my overall opinion of the game. I enjoyed it, and considering the cost of the game I felt like the investment was worth it. With so many games pushing 80+ hours to complete these days, it was refreshing to spend a buck for a few hours of entertainment.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												Polarity is a very fun game, don't get me wrong. However it has a glaring flaw that the rest of these reviews (as far as I've seen) haven't really addressed. That flaw is the game-breakingly bad jumping. I have played the game for .7 hours as of writing this review, and I can garauntee that at least 30 minutes of that have been dedicated to trying to jump. It only works every ~1/4 time you hit space, which makes parkour very difficult to do. Another (much more minor) grievance is the shadow quality of the game, as they are aliased to hell and back.The game itself is very fun, however. It reminds the player of portal, while still having its own uniqueness that keeps the player going. The polarity switch is a neat little feature, while not very practical in the actual game. (That is, it is necessary, but it does not contribute to any of the puzzles.) If the issue with jumping was to be fixed, I would recommend this game.

Posted: May 9, 2015
												Polarity is a fairly simple 3D first-person puzzle platformer.  It's rather short; I beat the single player game in one sitting in an afternoon.  The game also contains a split-screen co-op mode and a set of bonus levels.It lacks a lot of polish that makes similar puzzle games great: the menus are rather old looking, although the level select in the background is nice; there are a few clipping errors here and there, but nothing overt; the textures are a little flat, but there are is a nice shadow effect around the edges of things that make everything look a little bit nicer.The single player puzzles are rather easy, and the co-op puzzles seem to be a bit harder.  However, it seems that the co-op mode has even less polish than the main game, with the cube spawn sites not even having the fancy model that the single player campaign uses.I'd rate this game as a fairly good entry into the genre for someone who hasn't played much.  But for anyone looking for a well polished game or much of a challenge, it's best to look elsewhere.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												Good concept. Decent puzzle design most of the time, but lots of occasions where it felt like the level designer ran out of ideas in the middle before they came up with enough puzzles to hide the goal points (like that one level where the third goal point was *in the room with the level exit*. Really?) Occasionally felt more like hide and seek than full on puzzling. Doing more clever things with the Polarity Switch mechanic would be good since it is the game's namesake. Lots of graphical mistakes - Getting your texture edges lined up with your geometry has been level design 101 stuff since the DOOM .wad days, gang. The game is low budget and it looks it.  Still, it kept my attention for the hour or so it took to play through to the end. 99 cents might be a good price point for this - I feel like I got my 19 cents worth out of it.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												Anyone who says this game is anything like Portal or Portal 2 has never even once seen any other first-person puzzle game in their entire life. This game has some very minor similarities but in no way feels anything like portal. Now that that is out of the way we can talk about this game. Polarity is reasonably fun to play, you will constantly think you need the cubes and end up with one or two at the elevator and then later you will find out you're trying too hard on something that's easy if you bring another cube. Is this game worth 5 euros? No. It's too simple and short for that. But if it's on sale and you like first person puzzles you can grab this game and kill a couple of hours with this simple game. It's not very challenging but not too easy, and it has data fragments in some sneaky places for completionists out there. Graphics are okay, they're very simple which makes the game easy to read. Those who have played anti-chamber are sure to be able to solve anything in this game. All and all it's nothing too hard, nor too easy. Anyone who has played a couple of first person puzzlers will be able to solve this game, and for 0,19 euros it's worth for killing a couple of hours.

Posted: August 27, 2015
												Polarity is a below-average Portal knock-off that is childishly easy, but only made difficult in that you can’t fully remap your keyboard and mouse.Its unique premise is that you have red and blue “polarities”, with each color reflecting the other. How this works in the game is that if you have a blue laser fence up, you have to change to the blue polarity to get past. Alternately, if the floor is blue, change to red polarity so that you can walk on it. The only real challenges are when you have to flip back-and-forth between them quickly, such as when you’re jumping on alternating colors.The whole thing looks and feels like a college project with dreadfully simple layout, mismatched layers that caused me to continually “trip” every time I walked over a line, and simple challenges. The game features jumps but because they’re not flush with the wall, I kept getting stuck on those too.Definitely not worth $5, and really not worth the 90% discount that I got it at. You’d do better with just about any other title.

Posted: November 28, 2015
												1 Line review: It's like Portal, but without Portals. Also, it's very short. 5/10Full Review:There isn't much to talk about this. The story is almost non-existent and is just a bunch (~20 + 10 extras) of really short levels (5min max if you want to get everything in each level). I'd say that the concept is kinda cool: instead of Portals, you have you manipulate your own "polarity", between red or blue if you don't want to die from lasers of that color, if you want to be above platforms of those colors and even transport cubes of those colors without desintegrating them.As a puzzle game, I didn't find it hard, only slightly on very specific segments that you have to get some items to unlock the ending. It should be more as an introdutory puzzle game to kids ages 8 and lower rather than to teens and adults used to more complex games like The Talos Principle and PQ (the psp exclusive). If you fall on the latter category, this game should be just one or two hours long.On the other hand, this game often comes *really* cheap, like dirt cheap (some 50 cents... no pun intended), so the price/game hours ratio isn't that bad. The experience itself is bug-free and the visual is simple and a little retro, so it's nice to relax if you want something for that. Visuals are quite simple as well, but don't strain the eyes.Overall, it is a fair game... I mean, fairly standard. Short, cheap, soothing, but nothing more. Well, it has multiplayer, but it's not that entertaining as other puzzle multiplayer games. So, just don't expect much.

Posted: March 12
												Do you like simple puzzles? If you do you'll probably enjoy playing Polarity. On the other hand, if you prefer more complex puzzles, or don't like puzzles much at all, you might not. Polarity is a first person puzzle game similar to Portal (the objective is to exit the room by activating switches and the like), with the main difference being in the titular mechanic. Basically, some objects interact with other objects depending on their polarity. For example, red cubes will only activate red switches. You can also change your polarity at will for various effects. This mechanic is used in some way in every puzzle. The puzzles themselves have data (the game's collectibles) hidden throughout, and the main challenge comes from collecting all of the data. Data will also unlock new puzzles on the level select, as well as bonus puzzles (Note: data is not required to play most levels, but you will only be able to select most levels after meeting a data quota. For example, if you play through a level without meeting its data quota, you will be able  to proceed to the next level if you don't return to the menu; but if you do, you will only be able to select levels with completed quotas to begin from.).If I had to complain about one thing it would be that the game is pretty short. There are only about 20 single player levels. To be fair, the game does have a coop mode as well as a player vs player mode, but both of these are only local, and require a pad and a pal to play. As such, I've yet to try either (I'll place and edit here if I do). The game also doesn't have any story or characters to speak of; and while the graphics and sound work well enough, they don't really add that much to the game.But in the end it all comes down to one question. Do you like puzzles?

Posted: June 26, 2015
												This game is SHORT, but it's a lot of fun. It's in the vein of Portal but without anything but the mere hint of a story. You are a "hacker" who, instead of using computers at all, uses colored light and switches to achieve your aims, collecting "data fragments" that are just collectibles scattered throughout the level. This thin excuse for a story aside, it's got good mechanics. You can reverse your polarity to either red or blue to pass through lasers and forcefields, or have your polarity opposite so you can walk across light bridges. There are a lot of putting-cubes-on-switches and jumping through forcefields while changing your polarity midair, and it gets pretty easy near the end once you've gotten the hang of it. It feels like I just finished the tutorial level and am waiting for the bigger levels.8/10 overall, mostly for game length. You should definitely buy this, but don't pay more than $5 or you'll feel ripped off.

Posted: June 26, 2015
												I picked this up with 3 other games for $1.49 total, not knowing what to expect (despite having positive reviews) I was pleasantly surprised with all the games but especially with Polarity. In polarity you find yourself switching polarity to get through/over red and blue "gates" and throwing/dropping red and blue cubes to power up devices in order to get to the end of the level while also searching for Data Fragments to unlock bonus levels.Polarity is a simple, well-executed concept that makes the player feel good when they solve each puzzle. The game is casual friendly with it's level checkpoints, no real way to die and no enemies (at least in the levels I've played).The game could be better with a level editor, steam workshop and leaderboards to encourage players to replay levels, the cubes also sometimes don't do what you want while you are carrying them by seeming to bug out on rare occasions.I highly recommend this for fans of puzzle games and even the casual gamer looking for a new challenge but still want a relaxing game.

Posted: May 13, 2015
												Fantastic little puzzler. Nothing too taxing on the brain, but attempting to find all of the data packs (there are three of them hidden in each level) can be a real challenge and the idea of polarity-switching is used to good effect. The similarities to Portal are well-known at this point; you find yourself in a sleek, enclosed environment and use your wits (and cubes) to reach the exit. If you enjoyed Portal, you'll enjoy this, but it would be doing the game a disservice to call it a Portal clone; it has its own ideas and systems that are well thought-out and smoothly executed throughout. The game is void of any real plot or humour, but those things aren't needed here. It's a simple little game and quite a relaxing way to flex your puzzling muscles for an hour or two, without any extra baggage forcefully added on. I've not been able to enjoy the co-op campaign just yet, but if the singleplayer is anything to go by then it must be a lot of fun. There's certainly potential for a sequel here and I hope to see more from this developer in the future.

Posted: March 7, 2016
												First let's go over the good stuff. The puzzle mechanics are kinda interesting and will, at times, make quick use of them. The controls are as smooth as you expect from a recent game.Now for what I didn't like. The biggest problem is that all of the puzzles revolve around finding "data." To complete a level and progess to the next one, three orbs of data need to be found. The problem with this is that the difficulty of all of the puzzles come from finding the orbs on the board. They are almost never hard to get to, just hard to find. This would be okay if the developers realized this and made each level interesting. Turn each board into a unique easter egg hunt that reveals something about the story. Show something about my mysterious empoyer. Leave notes on the wall next to an orb that shows what each piece of data is. Have comments of code that reveals something about the owner. Make each nook and cranny rewarding to explore, even if it doesn't have an orb. As is, however, each level is like an easter egg hunt where all the eggs are hidden in 4 acre egg carton: everything looks the same until you stumble upon the green orb.For a game that is "demanding all of your wits and reflexes," this game is surprisingly easy and short. As mentioned earlier, almost all of the difficulty comes from finding all of the orbs. It's reminiscent of Knuckles' levels in Sonic Adventure, which we all know as everyone's favorite part of everyone's favorite game. What makes matters worse is that sometimes it is brutally apparent that the developers placed the orbs as an after thought just to squeeze three into each level. Each puzzle takes less than 5 minutes to complete, except one that I spent several extra minutes exploring the level looking for the last orb. Turns out it was in the exit room. Why even bother?Minor gripes: some small steps can't be walked over, they need to be jumped. At times the physics is unpredictable. For example, a cube won't move with a moving platform when placed on it. Also, the throwing mechanic sometimes makes it feel like I accidentally skipped part of a puzzle (might just be me, though). Less than one hour of main story, maybe another with extras, and maybe another with co-op.I like what they tried to do and the mechanics are cool, but the environment is unrewarding.TL;DR: The game controls well and has a neat idea. The execution is sub par, unchallenging, and short. Not worth $10. If you catch it on super sale (whatever 1-2 hours is worth to you), go ahead and try it.

Posted: July 11, 2015
												After selling a handfull of cards I got the game for just 20 cents. I've only played the single player mode, so all this is based only on that mode (no idea what co-op is like). The game takes a few things from Portal and Antichamber as well. The game mechanics, the launh pads, the blocks and the way blocks activate platforms is well known from Portal while the graphical style, the very simplistic, bold style with a thick black outline around certain objects looks pretty similar to Antichamber at times. I found the puzzles to be pretty easy to complete. Near the end the puzzles actually became more challenging, but yeah, that was at the end. Definitely not on the same difficulty level as Portal's chambers in my opinion. Having said that if you find Portal too challenging then this game might just be for you. Bare in mind though that you're going to want to play this for the puzzles and not for the story as there isn't much to it. Also if you're thinking about buying Portal but you're uncertain as to whether or not you'll like that kind of game then you may want to get this first given that it's quite similar in terms of gameplay and (at the moment) dirt cheap. Summary: For 20 cents the game is more than worth it. It's not that difficult in my opinion and could definitely use some more levels and perhaps a bit less headbobbing, but still well worth it.

Posted: July 25, 2015
												Solid core mechanic that is built off of over the course of the game. Levels take on average 3 minutes to complete and there aren't that many of them so it goes fast.Rather than using the same mechanic in harder and harder puzzles new mechanics are introduced. The introductions for these new mechanics are well done but they're never combined in a confusing way. I never once had to stop playing and think about what I had to do next. Solutions could typically be found by running in, looking around, and saying "oh" at which point it became a matter of execution. Or "how can I beat this in a way that was unintended?" depends on your mindset really.Game is fairly sparse visually and there are some physics bugs but nothing that takes away from the core puzzle mechanics. Posted: January 16, 2016
												I lost interest in under an hour. The puzzles are far too easy, and the difficuly curve is stagnant if it even exists. I may come back and beat it,  and I'm still glad I bought it, but If i had paid the full $10.99 for this I would be extremely dissapointed. I would recommend buying this game if it were under $2, and if you prefer relaxed puzzle games.Why is there a run button? I feel like no one wants to walk, but it was just added because a lot of games have one. The areas that make you run/jump and change colors require 4 key presses, shift being the most awkward, as though I'm playing twister with my hand. just make the player always run. Sometimes I'll throw a box at the wall to grab a data fragments, and the box goes through the wall. Two things here: data should be collected on contact, secondly, fix the wall glitch.I'm not a fan of the use and design of the UI. The tutorial buttons pause the game, almost always when I was in mid jump, for the first message, I had just happened to be clicking right as it popped up, and accidentally closed it after it showed for a 10th of a second. I never got a chance to read it. they should really just stay up, without pausing the game, and dissapear after a few seconds. lastly, I don't like that a "next level" button appears at the end, would be nicer if it just went to the next level.The game has a confusing optional yet kinda required data collection, side thing. I say take that out entirely, and force the player to do every puzzle. This would remove the need for back-tracking, level selection, and all of those things that break the immersion of the game. Most of the data finding added nothing to the game, other than make me bored whilst checking nooks and crannies. Only a few data hiding spot added some fun, and you might as well just work those into the mandatory path of the level.Story was non-existent, normally I don't care, but, it's just another example of how the game aimed low in all areas except... technical implementation: the game is almost bug free; It handles pretty well. The only bug I saw was mentioned earlier, Nothing else really annoyed me, outside of the game's design.Keep at it, and try to take more risks. It's a neat concept that can lead to a really great game, but it just needs better level design

Posted: January 18, 2016
												The description tries to lure you in by mentioning Portal, but don't be fooled.  It's a puzzle platformer with a tech theme (though something tells me it's just an excuse to be minimalist in their design - the story consists of a few lines of dialogue slapped on the beginning and end of the game), and you place boxes on pads to advance.  The similarities end there.The puzzles mostly consist of finding where to place a block to activate a bridge or jump pad.  Once you look around and locate it, it's usually just a matter or pointing and clicking to throw.  It will go in a perfectly straight line as far as it needs to and when it gets there it will be sucked in by the switch.  Not a puzzle, just basic observation skills. Some of the pads require you to bounce it off a wall, and those have very clearly marked targets.  Just "throw here to advance."  The other aspect of the game is toggling between red and blue, which changes which bridges you can use and which you'll fall through.  At the beginning these are pretty easy except that the default keybindings aren't great (and only remappable before launching the game) and coordinating it is rough.  I'm willing to accept that this is a deficiency on my part, and the controls may be more intuitive with a controller. Near the end, this aspect was getting challenging enough to be worthwhile on its own, but just as it got interesting, game over.On one level, I spent 15 minutes trying to solve what appeared to be an interesting puzzle just to find that the solution was just to push a big button.  I beat it 100% (excluding co-op) in 2 hours, and it was mildly entertaining.  But I also got it on sale for 50 cents.  It's definitely not worth $10.99.

Posted: May 9, 2015
												Polarity is a fairly simple 3D first-person puzzle platformer.  It's rather short; I beat the single player game in one sitting in an afternoon.  The game also contains a split-screen co-op mode and a set of bonus levels.It lacks a lot of polish that makes similar puzzle games great: the menus are rather old looking, although the level select in the background is nice; there are a few clipping errors here and there, but nothing overt; the textures are a little flat, but there are is a nice shadow effect around the edges of things that make everything look a little bit nicer.The single player puzzles are rather easy, and the co-op puzzles seem to be a bit harder.  However, it seems that the co-op mode has even less polish than the main game, with the cube spawn sites not even having the fancy model that the single player campaign uses.I'd rate this game as a fairly good entry into the genre for someone who hasn't played much.  But for anyone looking for a well polished game or much of a challenge, it's best to look elsewhere.

Posted: September 7, 2016
												General Pros:To be fair, it's not a bad game. The gameplay is solid, the physics are mostly solid (excluding bugs), the graphics are a bit lacklustre, but are generally clean and consistent, it has trading cards, it's a good time and the game goes on sale enough to be worth its sale price. I would only buy this game when the sales go for 3$CAD (2.50$USD) or under.General Cons:Why so many negative reviews? Sketchy devs, graphics problems, frame rate issues, general bugs, uninteresting story, very easy, no replay value, general mediocrity and no online co-op. For more information, read some negative reviews.Why the up rating:I actually enjoyed the game for the price I got it at. The single player is generally quite easy, but there was enough challenge to keep me interested for casual play. The co-op is a good time if you have the controllers to do it. It's well designed and harder than the single-player levels. If you're looking for your typical impossible puzzle game that feeds the weak to the gods of "online guides" with tons of levels ranking up to an impossible difficulty, go somewhere else. It's a rather short game that's fairly easy to complete. It's too short to get repetitive, but long enough to get engaged in. I personally like this style, but it's not for everyone and thus, I'm recommending it, but not for everyone :D

Posted: September 9, 2016
Product received for free
												With a puzzle structure similar to that of the "Portal" nature, it is easy to see this game as a rip off. Although, it is very much it's own game. having being built by a very small team as a hobby, it is obvious that this is not going to be a AAA title. But it's not neccissarily bad. A few object placement errors here and there, and fairly basic gameplay does not make a bad game. Also, both of these can be fixed with a bit of time and an update.The first half hour playing this game, the only frustration I had was a small one at that; The constant tutorial popups. They just got slightly annoying, but tollerable. Other than that, I found the game to be playable and enjoyable. Like I mentioned, the game has a portal-like puzzle structure with similar mechanics, but they are not completely the same. Overall, considering the small dev team and the time put into the game, I would say the game is really not bad. It's a fun, entertaining little something to do that passes time, which, for a small indie puzzle game, is all I expect it to be and do.I have recieved this game for free as a gift from te developers and I am appreciative of the free game. Thanks guys!

Posted: September 8, 2016
Product received for free
 TL;DR It's a pretty solid game with the few exceptions of bugs and painfully simple puzzles The game is pretty much a straight rip of Portal, but still enjoyable at times the game has many "borrowed" (Borrowed being the more generous term) mechanics for Portal ie. companion cube-esque puzzles, avoiding laser on a moving platform, etc. However, the game still makes for a fun and light puzzle game to pass an afternoon, but don't expect it to take up too much time. At this point, I have beaten this game (including bonus levels) with just over two hours, and I don't know if I really want to invite some on over to play the co-op missions(no online co-op). The game is sprinkled with a few bugs that were not really unexpected from a small indie dev, but can be annoying none the less (ie. clipping issues with cubes or cubes just straight up disappearing).Overall, if you're looking to  play  a first person puzzle game that comes with some real challenge and story, just pick up the portal bundle. However if you're just looking for a way to throw away a few hours on something sort of challenging and fun, and this game happens to be on sale, why not but I wouldn't recommend paying the full price, I mean I got it for free.
