Posted: May 13, 2015
												Fantastic little puzzler. Nothing too taxing on the brain, but attempting to find all of the data packs (there are three of them hidden in each level) can be a real challenge and the idea of polarity-switching is used to good effect. The similarities to Portal are well-known at this point; you find yourself in a sleek, enclosed environment and use your wits (and cubes) to reach the exit. If you enjoyed Portal, you'll enjoy this, but it would be doing the game a disservice to call it a Portal clone; it has its own ideas and systems that are well thought-out and smoothly executed throughout. The game is void of any real plot or humour, but those things aren't needed here. It's a simple little game and quite a relaxing way to flex your puzzling muscles for an hour or two, without any extra baggage forcefully added on. I've not been able to enjoy the co-op campaign just yet, but if the singleplayer is anything to go by then it must be a lot of fun. There's certainly potential for a sequel here and I hope to see more from this developer in the future.

Posted: May 12, 2015
												I was having a reasonable amount of fun until I got to level five, which, unless I'm completely mistaken about the puzzle's solution, involves jumping from a moving platform to a stationary platform, perpendicularly to the motion of the former. We've all done this in hundreds of games before without a problem, but this game doesn't seem to understand the concept of inertia. Assuming I'm jumping forward at the same speed the platform is moving, the combined momentum should result in a vector 45 degrees between either axis of motion. Instead, the instant I jump the platform's momentum seems to double, sending me shooting out, impossibly, ahead of the moving platform. In what $%&#ing physics does this make any sense? Has no one else had this problem? Is it foreshadowing later puzzles in which this bizarre characteristic of moving platforms is part of the solution? I'm too frustrated to stick around and find out. Luckily I only paid 19 cents for the game. That said, it might have been worth the asking price of $4.99 if this physics glitch didn't render it unplayable. Glad everyone else seems to enjoy it, though.

Posted: May 13, 2015
												This game has a very simple purpose: to be a puzzle game from a small time developer working on their own. Does it work? To a point, maybe. It does have some things that challenge you to think for a minute, but there's nothing really challenging about the puzzles themselves. The only challenge is that sometimes your character won't move in the right way, and that's something out of our control. Does it satisfy my puzzle addiction in the way Portal did? Not a chance. This is way more obvious than Portal. This is more of a skill game than a puzzle game.

Posted: October 21, 2016
												Don't let the bad reviews stop you from getting this game.Did I buy it? Yes. Was it worth it? Definitely.While this game was short and quite clearly a Portal-style remake, Polarity is a fun 3D Platform game. The goal is to get to the end of each stage while collecting data fragments along the way (there are 3 for each stage). Using only your intelligence and a few colored cubes placed in specific locations on the map, you run and jump through 11 stages in story, 10 stages of bonus levels and some stages in Co-op (I admit, though, I never tried Co-op). While simplistic, the challenge of collecting the data chips makes it a little more exciting. It's a nice, simple, short game, that is still worth playing.The only con I would have to say is the ending.. It left me wanting more. A lot more. As for the soundtrack? I actually liked it. It was catchy. tl;dr short, fun 3D platform game that can be a little challenging, but wish it was longer. The music is now permanently engraved into my brain.8.5/10

Posted: October 22, 2016
												On the whole, a very nice game. The puzzles have some interesting twists and the asthetic is nice.There does seem to be a little lack of polish. The textures dont always lign up correctly and there are 2 level 10's in coop and no 11, most annoyingly is the where floors that should be flat have a slight lip on  that can allow the character to get stuck on what appears to be nothing.It should be noted that walking is far too slow, at least for me. This means I have to hold run all the time... if there was always run or if run was a toggle, the problem would be aliviated.Noe that coop is split screen, considering the only gaming friends I have play over the net, a network coop would mean I sont have to play both players, which is cumbersom.As far as coop goes, there is not much integration between the two players. For the most part, you complete your half of the level and the other player either completes theirs, or just just go to the finish.All in all, a fun game and worth playing, just a little short with a few issues.

Posted: June 26, 2015
												This game is SHORT, but it's a lot of fun. It's in the vein of Portal but without anything but the mere hint of a story. You are a "hacker" who, instead of using computers at all, uses colored light and switches to achieve your aims, collecting "data fragments" that are just collectibles scattered throughout the level. This thin excuse for a story aside, it's got good mechanics. You can reverse your polarity to either red or blue to pass through lasers and forcefields, or have your polarity opposite so you can walk across light bridges. There are a lot of putting-cubes-on-switches and jumping through forcefields while changing your polarity midair, and it gets pretty easy near the end once you've gotten the hang of it. It feels like I just finished the tutorial level and am waiting for the bigger levels.8/10 overall, mostly for game length. You should definitely buy this, but don't pay more than $5 or you'll feel ripped off.

												I will say that this game is fairly easy and there isn't much to it, but that doesn't make it bad. Sure, it's short, it isn't nearly as challenging as an other puzzle game I've played (Portal, The Talos Priciple, Portal 2, etc.), and it likes to stutter from time to time, but it is only $0.54....oh wait...that's the price at 95% off >,> And if you are wondering, it IS possible to play most of the co-op levels by yourself, I am working on the rest of them when I find the time, for those of you without any friends....that play this game of course...because I have friends....they...just don't play this game.But like I said before, it isn't a bad game, but it really isn't worth the $20.00 it would cost you if it wasn't on sale.I'd rate it higher if the price was either lower than twenty dollars or if it had more content, but for now, I'd give it a 4/10.

Posted: January 16, 2016
												I lost interest in under an hour. The puzzles are far too easy, and the difficuly curve is stagnant if it even exists. I may come back and beat it,  and I'm still glad I bought it, but If i had paid the full $10.99 for this I would be extremely dissapointed. I would recommend buying this game if it were under $2, and if you prefer relaxed puzzle games.Why is there a run button? I feel like no one wants to walk, but it was just added because a lot of games have one. The areas that make you run/jump and change colors require 4 key presses, shift being the most awkward, as though I'm playing twister with my hand. just make the player always run. Sometimes I'll throw a box at the wall to grab a data fragments, and the box goes through the wall. Two things here: data should be collected on contact, secondly, fix the wall glitch.I'm not a fan of the use and design of the UI. The tutorial buttons pause the game, almost always when I was in mid jump, for the first message, I had just happened to be clicking right as it popped up, and accidentally closed it after it showed for a 10th of a second. I never got a chance to read it. they should really just stay up, without pausing the game, and dissapear after a few seconds. lastly, I don't like that a "next level" button appears at the end, would be nicer if it just went to the next level.The game has a confusing optional yet kinda required data collection, side thing. I say take that out entirely, and force the player to do every puzzle. This would remove the need for back-tracking, level selection, and all of those things that break the immersion of the game. Most of the data finding added nothing to the game, other than make me bored whilst checking nooks and crannies. Only a few data hiding spot added some fun, and you might as well just work those into the mandatory path of the level.Story was non-existent, normally I don't care, but, it's just another example of how the game aimed low in all areas except... technical implementation: the game is almost bug free; It handles pretty well. The only bug I saw was mentioned earlier, Nothing else really annoyed me, outside of the game's design.Keep at it, and try to take more risks. It's a neat concept that can lead to a really great game, but it just needs better level design

Posted: August 14, 2016
												TL;DR: I recommend this game, but not at this price.To get it out of the way: There have been some accusations of shady behavior. First: the release date of the game changed several times, putting it back on the new releases list. The dev claims this was due to a bug, many claim it was done intentionally to get the new releases publicity. I follow the axiom of "never ascribe to malice what can be explained by incompetence" and so I'm willing to give them the benefit of the doubt.The other thing is that the price of this game has changed several times. This is fully within a game dev's rights, and the dev's claim that when the price has changed it has stayed that way for a decent length of time rather than quick changes to game the sales seems to hold (mostly) true. You can see the sale data at http://steamsales.rhekua.com/search.php?term=Polarity the July 15, 2016 spike is the only part that does seem a little shady. At the end of the day, the pricing data is available, and as a consumer you should be doing your research about purchases rather than getting sucked in by sale percentages.So the game itself. Worth $10? no, sorry. Thing is, the game has gone on sale many times, for as low as 19 cents. Wait until it's less than a dollar, or part of a cheap bundle to pick it up. Alternatively, you can get this game for actually free if you have "Out There Somewhere", another game by the same dev, and give them your email in the launcher.The game itself is pretty solid FOR DIRT CHEAP. It's not a great game by any means. It's pretty short. At no point in the main or bonus stages (didn't play the co-op) did I ever feel like a puzzle was challenging. The game introduces a lot of mechanics that could have been explored in more depth with much more complicated puzzles, but just weren't, such as the rotatable launchers that you almost never have to rotate. The game also has its fair share of bugs, for instance I was able to clip cubes through floors a few times, I managed to bypass an entire puzzle just by jumping to the exit, and I also managed to get in a configuration that soft locked a level, forcing me to restart from the beginning.Other than that, I did enjoy my short time with the game. The puzzles generally took a little bit of tinkering with to get all the data, even though they're completely straightforward. I originally started this as a positive review, but I realized that the only way I could recommend the game was with the thought "what can you expect for less than a dollar?" But it isn't less than a dollar, it's currently 10, and as a 10 dollar game it's garbage.

Posted: October 13, 2016
												A fun and relatively novel puzzle game. While the puzzles border on trivial in places the game make use of some interesting game play elements. I really like the idea of the switching polarity and I think there is a lot of potential to expand upon the mechanic. The level design is simple but appealing and the soundtrack has a nice ambient, soothing quality that I think really suits the gameplay.The only real complaints I have are the polish, difficulty, and length of the game.During gameplay, there wer scattered instances of getting caught on small edges and sequences of accelerators. I don't think it detracts from gameplay too much but with the timing component it seems like this has potential to frustrate speed runners.The difficulty is obviously subjective and I understand that it can be difficult to strike a balance here. I think the game would benefit from the addition of more challenging puzzles, either by developer addition, or support for community creation.The campaign and bonus levels felt a bit short overall. Obviously there could be replay value for people wanting to improve time overal but without a leaderboard for friends this might be rather niche.Overall, I like the game and recommend it for people who like relaxing puzzle games.

Posted: October 21, 2016
												Don't let the bad reviews stop you from getting this game.Did I buy it? Yes. Was it worth it? Definitely.While this game was short and quite clearly a Portal-style remake, Polarity is a fun 3D Platform game. The goal is to get to the end of each stage while collecting data fragments along the way (there are 3 for each stage). Using only your intelligence and a few colored cubes placed in specific locations on the map, you run and jump through 11 stages in story, 10 stages of bonus levels and some stages in Co-op (I admit, though, I never tried Co-op). While simplistic, the challenge of collecting the data chips makes it a little more exciting. It's a nice, simple, short game, that is still worth playing.The only con I would have to say is the ending.. It left me wanting more. A lot more. As for the soundtrack? I actually liked it. It was catchy. tl;dr short, fun 3D platform game that can be a little challenging, but wish it was longer. The music is now permanently engraved into my brain.8.5/10

												A fun puzzle game.However DO NOT purchase this game for its full price tag.  The story is short (so far?), and only took me a little over an hour.  Buy when its on sale (I got it for $0.19)With that being said, the gameplay does remind of portal for a few aspects. Posted: October 22, 2015
												The Good-Enjoyable portal clone-Gameplay is quite fun-Music is solid-Relatively unique visual style (reminds me of Tron)-Teaches the player controlls without holding their hand in learning gameplay mechanicsThe Meh Stuff-Sounds were hit and miss - example: jump sounds were bad and off time with visuals fairly often but sounds for the cube and polarity shift were good-Gameplay elements were unique but there are only a few to learnThe Bad-EXTREMELY short game - I finished the single player and bonus missions in one sitting; less than an hour and a half total-The jump mechanics do not function very well, especially when trying to make multiple jumps in a row. This makes some levels a bit frustrating.-EXTREMELY easy game - even the most "challenging" levels only take a couple minutes to finish. Several of the data (the things you collect each level) are in plain sight or hidden in painfully obvious hiding places. There is little to no challange in the puzzles. Overall, I thought the game was enjoyable but definately not worth $11. I did not play the coop or vs modes, so perhaps these modes give some extra worth. I bought it on sale so it was dirt cheap. TL;DRBUY IT IF IT IS ON SALE, DON'T BUY IT IF IT IS NOT ON SALE

Posted: December 28, 2016
												Very short game. Finished both the "story" and the bonus levels in less than 2 hours. There are a few more co-op levels, but those require either two "pads" (gamepad?) or a keyboard and gamepad.Overall the levels are on the simple side. Some of the bonus levels are broken (in the sense that you can skip half the puzzle). The player model gets stuck on ledges, and cubes will not follow the player physics very well, causing it to move sluggish, or to fall right through a moving platform. The mouse sensitivity is set very high by default (360 turns with less than a cm mouse movement), but can be turned down from the main menu.Overall I think there are better puzzle games for this price.

												I recommend this game, however, there are some warnings.There are some bugs, in that you get hung up on tiny ledges--if the ledges aren't smooth you have to jump. Quite annoying way to deal with an uneven ledge (like having to jump up stairs because the game doesn't know how to move you through, even 1 inch of difference). Posted: January 12
												The game is quite good. Nothing amazing compared to Portal or even last year's The Turing Test, but still fun while it lasted. The Puzzles are fairly easy and there aren't too many of them (22, not counting the dedicated co-op levels that I haven't tried yet), so definitely bear in mind that playtime is limited to a bit less than two hours for singleplayer. That is, if you have played Portal-esque games before.In a lot of negative reviews you can read that the game feels unfinished. While it is true that the graphics look kinda ugly for a 2014 release, I personally didn't expect much more with this being an Ouya-port. On the other hand, gameplay-wise I don't really see where the complaints are coming from. I never found myself in a deadlock due to bad level design (not that I looked for one, but yeah) and it never felt like I would be fighting with the controls or anything. Throwing boxes around often takes a bit of trial and error, but it didn't reach the point of me getting frustrated or anything.The Levels, again, are fairly easy, but they do have a nice progression to them with the bonus levels, unlocking after the main campaign, being the most interesting ones.Story-wise, it's pretty forgettable. Something about hacking a secure computer system and extracting sensitive data, but it could really be anyting as it never comes into play in the levels themselves.I guess I would be more harsh to the game if I had paid full price, but for the current asking price of 99 cents, I got what I was looking for.

Posted: April 30, 2016
												The game has potential but there are some large problems: 1. It is not particularly well optomized, for a small game with small arenas I had significant stuttering in later levels. I have had less in some levels of the 2013 Tomb Raider.2. The game is not very polished, a bit the opposite. Numerous obvious graphical issues, clipping, and inability to scale very small steps due to bounceback became major annoyances as the game wore on.3. The levels were easy. Really easy. None took more than 10 mins to complete, and all were quite simple. The only difficult ones were harder due to lack of understanding more than actual gameplay challenge.4. The main issue however is the price to gameplay ratio. In less than an hour and a half (87 minutes in fact) I completed the entire story and every bonus level, collecting 100% of their data. The only part I did not do was the multiplayer since it is local only and only playable with 1 or more controllers. I was able to complete the first multiplayer level solo in less than 5 mins, but both players must reach the end to win. I recieved the game for free due to my purchase of another game (Particle Mace), and got 1.5 hours of mild enjoyment. For the full price, 11 dollars, this is absolutely ridiculous. Paying 11 dollars for an hour and a half of gameplay is about as good a deal as purchasing The Order: 1886.Edit: I tried local multiplayer with a steam controller and keyboard, the controller character's movements were delayed by like 20 seconds, absolutely unplayable.

Posted: February 5
												Portal for people with bad computers (I mean for those who want to play Portal 2), no portal mechanics but everything else seems to be the same gameplay, would recommend it if it wasn't at this price, I'd pay 2usd or less for this game, since there's nothing original about it, okay there's SOME mechanics that this game has and Portal doesn't, and viceversa, but it's not enough. Besides not being original, it's not that fun anyway, also too short. The plot is a joke "you are a hacker, win the game and I give you money" "you won the game, have the money, and we will hire you to do more of the same", there's no plot at all in the game besides intro and when you beat the last level, which is literally just the text I said but without being simplified. There's a lot of obvious to find bugs and levels that were designed in a rush and are flawed af. Examples: You can force a red cube through a blue laser wall by pushing yourself against it, which is pretty gamebreaking, I wasn't even sure if it was a bug or not at start, how could they let such a bug in the game. If you stand in a part of a level where you can spin the walls with a button, and do it, you will get stuck in the wall while it spins, and when it stops spinning you go flying upwards (and stop being stuck)I admit I didn't try coop yet but I don't think the experience will be any different.TL;DR Go buy Portal instead

Posted: April 30, 2016
												The game has potential but there are some large problems: 1. It is not particularly well optomized, for a small game with small arenas I had significant stuttering in later levels. I have had less in some levels of the 2013 Tomb Raider.2. The game is not very polished, a bit the opposite. Numerous obvious graphical issues, clipping, and inability to scale very small steps due to bounceback became major annoyances as the game wore on.3. The levels were easy. Really easy. None took more than 10 mins to complete, and all were quite simple. The only difficult ones were harder due to lack of understanding more than actual gameplay challenge.4. The main issue however is the price to gameplay ratio. In less than an hour and a half (87 minutes in fact) I completed the entire story and every bonus level, collecting 100% of their data. The only part I did not do was the multiplayer since it is local only and only playable with 1 or more controllers. I was able to complete the first multiplayer level solo in less than 5 mins, but both players must reach the end to win. I recieved the game for free due to my purchase of another game (Particle Mace), and got 1.5 hours of mild enjoyment. For the full price, 11 dollars, this is absolutely ridiculous. Paying 11 dollars for an hour and a half of gameplay is about as good a deal as purchasing The Order: 1886.Edit: I tried local multiplayer with a steam controller and keyboard, the controller character's movements were delayed by like 20 seconds, absolutely unplayable.

Posted: April 15
												A simple puzzle game.Let me say this up front, I was very close to hating this game, and giving it a negative review. Then I realized the cubes can be respawned back at their original places.Once I knew that, and had no reason to restart at every little miss throw of the cube, the game went on without a hitch.Polarity is one of those games that you can't really find anything wrong with. It's indie so you can't blame it for small unpolished things, like say getting caught on stairs so you have to jump. However, even with nothing wrong, that doesn't mean that it has enough things right to be perfect.Still a good game though.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												There is a read me option on the main menu that explains this game was made by a small team working part time, which makes me sympathetic. I know now why the game isn't very good. I do not know how they think it is worth $10 dollars.Pros:The graphics will not offend you.Cons:This game has a story if you believe reading the menu at a Mexican restaraunt is equivalent to watching a tella novela.I was constantly getting stuck on slight inclines on the floor. Where it happened most? The tunnels leading to and from every level.Blocks can disappear behind walls or flat out disappear for seemingly no reason. You also stop holding the block if you are holding it close to the wall, for some reason.Platforming sections feel like you are being punished for no reason, with instant death pits in the middle of the room when you could have just made more floor and jump distances that flip a coin as to whether or not you actually stick to the very edge of the platform you are expected to jump on to.Some gameplay features are never explained. If you had to search how to even begin Level 10, you know what I am talking about.Overall:You shouldn't expect anything great. The biggest puzzle of this game is figuring out why the floors and walls of this place are screwing with you. Play this only if you have just played Portal for the millionth time and still want to solve puzzles, but are worried because you now hear Glados talking everywhere you go. And even then, you should only buy it on sale or as a part of a bundle, like I did.

Posted: March 5
												I would only recommend this game if it is on sale for a few dollars. It was fun, but I was able to beat the single player, including bonus levels, in about two hours. Puzzles aren't as difficult as other games and the "story" isn't really a story. I got the game on sale and it was an entertaining two hours. Can't comment on the multiplayer. There is a bug with higher refresh rate monitors; I had to turn my refresh rate down to 60 Hz because I couldn't jump whenever I wanted to jump. It was hit or miss at 144 Hz and dropping the refresh rate took care of the issue completely.

Posted: April 24
												I bought the game for 0,19€. I completed 100% of achievements in 3h 50mins (needed to start over after re-format). I completed the "co-op" campaing 95% alone, playing with 2 controllers. Only one of the puzzles required timing so I had my girlfriend play that one through with me. I would not recommend this game because the puzzles were not challenging at all. You don't get the same kind of excitement that you get from "the game" this game tries to cash in on. The "data" that you collect is usually hidden in a place that isn't required to access to complete the puzzle, I found this to be stupid, made me replay few maps. The graphics are alright, little bit monotone though. Most of the maps are "too big" so you spend large amount of time just running around, not "completing a puzzle".
